title: Data definition
description: How to map the input data.
ai_section:
## Evaluations Overview
To run evaluations, create a `Dataset` object with a `DataDefinition`, mapping column types and roles. This ensures Evidently processes the data correctly. For certain evaluations, specific columns are necessary. The mapping can be defined using the Python API or visually in the Evidently platform when uploading data.

title: Data definition
description: How to map the input data.
ai_section:
## Basic Flow to Create a Dataset
**Step 1. Imports:**  
Import the necessary modules:

```python
from evidently import Dataset
from evidently import DataDefinition
```

**Step 2. Prepare your data:**  
Utilize a `pandas.DataFrame`. Your data can have a flexible structure with a mix of column types. 

**Step 3. Create a Dataset object:**  
Use `Dataset.from_pandas` with `data_definition` to initialize the object.

```python
eval_data = Dataset.from_pandas(
    source_df,
    data_definition=DataDefinition()
)
```

**Step 4. Run evaluations:**  
Once the **Dataset** object is set up, add Descriptors and run Reports.

title: Data definition
description: How to map the input data.
ai_section:
## Special Cases in Dataset Usage
**Working directly with pandas.DataFrame:**  
You may pass a `pandas.DataFrame` directly to `report.run()` for simple checks. However, creating a `Dataset` object is recommended for clarity.

**Working with two datasets:**  
When working with current and reference datasets for drift detection, ensure both have identical data definitions.

title: Data definition
description: How to map the input data.
ai_section:
## Understanding Data Definition
This section outlines mapping options for a `DataDefinition`. Only use the relevant mappings for your evaluation scenario.

title: Data definition
description: How to map the input data.
ai_section:
## Column Types in Data Definition
Understanding column types ensures correct statistics, visualizations, and default tests.

### Text Data
Specify input/output columns as text for LLM evaluations.

```python
definition = DataDefinition(
    text_columns=["Latest_Review"]
)
```

### Tabular Data
Map numerical, categorical, or datetime columns explicitly to avoid misclassification. 

```python
definition = DataDefinition(
    text_columns=["Latest_Review"],
    numerical_columns=["Age", "Salary"],
    categorical_columns=["Department"],
    datetime_columns=["Joining_Date"]
)
```

title: Data definition
description: How to map the input data.
ai_section:
## Default Column Types
If no explicit mapping is provided, the following defaults apply:

| **Column Type**       | **Description**                                                                                                                       | **Automated Mapping**                               |
|

title: Data definition
description: How to map the input data.

title: Data definition
description: How to map the input data.

title: Data definition
description: How to map the input data.
ai_section:
|
| `numerical_columns`   | Columns containing numeric values.                                                                                                   | All `np.number` type columns.                       |
| `datetime_columns`    | Columns containing datetime values.                                                                                                   | All `np.datetime64` type columns.                  |
| `categorical_columns` | Columns containing categorical values.                                                                                                | All non-numeric/non-datetime columns.               |
| `text_columns`        | Text columns that require mapping for drift detection.                                                                               | No automated mapping.                               |

title: Data definition
description: How to map the input data.
ai_section:
## ID and Timestamp Columns
If you have an ID or timestamp column, it's beneficial to identify them within the `DataDefinition`.

```python
definition = DataDefinition(
    id_column="Id",
    timestamp="Date"
)
```

title: Data definition
description: How to map the input data.
ai_section:
## LLM Evaluations and Descriptors
When generating text descriptors, they are automatically included in the Data Definition. If external scores or metadata are computed, map them explicitly in the `DataDefinition`.

```python
definition = DataDefinition(
    numerical_descriptors=["chat_length", "user_rating"],
    categorical_descriptors=["upvotes", "model_type"]
)
```

title: Data definition
description: How to map the input data.
ai_section:
## Regression Checks
To run regression checks, map the target and prediction columns.

```python
definition = DataDefinition(
    regression=[Regression(target="y_true", prediction="y_pred")]
)
```

Defaults are:

```python
    target: str = "target"
    prediction: str = "prediction"
```

title: Data definition
description: How to map the input data.
ai_section:
## Classification Checks
For classification checks, target and predicted labels/probabilities must be mapped appropriately.

### Multiclass Example Mapping
```python
data_def = DataDefinition(
    classification=[MulticlassClassification(
        target="target",
        prediction_labels="prediction",
        prediction_probas=["0", "1", "2"],
        labels={"0": "class_0", "1": "class_1", "2": "class_2"}
    )]
)
```

### Binary Example Mapping
```python
definition = DataDefinition(
    classification=[BinaryClassification(
        target="target",
        prediction_labels="prediction")],
    categorical_columns=["target", "prediction"]
)
```

title: Data definition
description: How to map the input data.
ai_section:
## Ranking Evaluations for Recommender Systems
Map columns with prediction and relevance labels for recommender system evaluations. Predictions can either be scores or ranks.

### Example for Score Predictions
| user_id | item_id | prediction (score) | target (relevance) |
|

title: Data definition
description: How to map the input data.
ai_section:
|
| user_1  | item_1  | 1.95               | 0                  |
| user_1  | item_2  | 0.8                | 1                  |

### Example for Rank Predictions
| user_id | item_id | prediction (rank) | target (relevance) |
|

title: Data definition
description: How to map the input data.

title: Data definition
description: How to map the input data.
ai_section:
|
| user_1  | item_1  | 1                 | 0                  |
| user_1  | item_2  | 2                 | 1                  |

Example mapping could be:

```python
definition = DataDefinition(
    ranking=[Recsys()]
)
```

title: Descriptors
description: How to run evaluations for text data.
ai_section:
## Evaluating Text Data with Descriptors
To evaluate text data, like LLM inputs and outputs, you create **Descriptors**. This universal interface allows various evaluations, ranging from text statistics to LLM judges. Each descriptor computes a score or label for each row in your dataset, and you can combine multiple descriptors with optional pass/fail conditions. Custom descriptors can be created using LLM prompts or Python.

title: Descriptors
description: How to run evaluations for text data.
ai_section:
## Basic Flow for Creating Sample Data
To generate sample data for testing, you can use the provided Python code snippet with pandas. This snippet creates a DataFrame containing sample questions and answers, which can be utilized for further evaluation.

```python
import pandas as pd

data = [
    ["What is the chemical symbol for gold?", "The chemical symbol for gold is Au."],
    ["What is the capital of Japan?", "The capital of Japan is Tokyo."],
    ...
]

columns = ["question", "answer"]
df = pd.DataFrame(data, columns=columns)
```

title: Descriptors
description: How to run evaluations for text data.
ai_section:
## Importing Required Modules
For conducting evaluations, you need to import specific modules from evidently:

```python
from evidently import Dataset
from evidently import DataDefinition
from evidently import Report

from evidently.descriptors import *
from evidently.presets import TextEvals
```

**Note**: Some descriptors may require downloading NLTK dictionaries.

title: Descriptors
description: How to run evaluations for text data.
ai_section:
## Adding Descriptors to Dataset
You can add descriptors to the Dataset object in two ways: during the creation of the Dataset or afterwards with the `add_descriptors` method.

**Option A**: Create the `Dataset` and add descriptors simultaneously.

```python
eval_dataset = Dataset.from_pandas(
    df,
    data_definition=DataDefinition(text_columns=["question", "answer"]),
    descriptors=[
        Sentiment("answer", alias="Sentiment"),
        TextLength("answer", alias="Length"),
        ...
    ]
)
```

title: Descriptors
description: How to run evaluations for text data.
ai_section:
## Exporting Results from Dataset
You can preview the DataFrame with results using the following command:

```python
eval_dataset.as_dataframe()
```

Additionally, you can generate a report that summarizes the results for all descriptors.

title: Descriptors
description: How to run evaluations for text data.
ai_section:
## Generating Evaluation Reports
To summarize results capturing stats and distributions for all descriptors, use the `TextEvals` Preset to configure and run the report for your dataset.

```python
report = Report([
    TextEvals()
])
my_eval = report.run(eval_dataset)
```

You can choose to export the report in various formats such as HTML, JSON, or Python dictionary.

title: Descriptors
description: How to run evaluations for text data.
ai_section:
## Customizing Descriptors
Evidently provides several descriptors with optional parameters. Adding an `alias` to each descriptor is recommended for easier reference in visualizations. 

```python
eval_dataset.add_descriptors(descriptors=[
    WordCount("answer", alias="Words"),
])
```

You can also create multi-column descriptors for evaluations that involve more than one text column.

title: Descriptors
description: How to run evaluations for text data.
ai_section:
## Implementing Descriptor Tests
Descriptor Tests allow you to define specific pass/fail conditions for each row. For instance, you can check if the text length is under a certain limit or that sentiment is positive.

**Step 1**: Import necessary modules.

```python
from evidently.descriptors import ColumnTest, TestSummary
```

**Step 2**: Add tests while creating a descriptor.

```python
eval_dataset = Dataset.from_pandas(
    df,
    data_definition=DataDefinition(text_columns=["question", "answer"]),
    descriptors=[
        Sentiment("answer", alias="Sentiment", tests=[gte(0, alias="Sentiment is non-negative")]),
        ...
    ]
)
```

title: Descriptors
description: How to run evaluations for text data.
ai_section:
## Creating Summary Reports
In addition to using `TextEvals`, you can create custom reports using different metric combinations for enhanced control.

**Imports**: Import the necessary components.

```python
from evidently import Report
from evidently.presets import TextEvals
from evidently.metrics import *
```

You can also run advanced checks, such as detecting text length drift by comparing two datasets.

title: Descriptors
description: How to run evaluations for text data.
ai_section:
## Dataset-Level Test Suites
You can attach tests to your metrics to receive pass/fail results at the dataset report level. Examples of such tests include validating that no response has a sentiment below a certain threshold.

```python
tests = Report([
    ...
])
```

title: Descriptors
description: How to run evaluations for text data.
ai_section:
## Custom Metrics Evaluation
You can create custom evaluations using metrics such as `MeanValue` and `MaxValue` to analyze your dataset. For example, you can compute the mean sentiment score and the length of responses:

```python
custom_report = Report([
    MeanValue(column="Length"),
    MeanValue(column="Sentiment")
])

my_custom_eval = custom_report.run(eval_dataset, None)
my_custom_eval
```

title: Descriptors
description: How to run evaluations for text data.
ai_section:
## Drift Detection
Drift detection allows you to compare distributions between two datasets to identify changes, such as variations in text length. For instance, you can detect length drift as follows:

```python
custom_report = Report([
    ValueDrift(column="Length"),
])

my_custom_eval = custom_report.run(eval_dataset, eval_dataset)
my_custom_eval
```

title: Descriptors
description: How to run evaluations for text data.
ai_section:
## Dataset-level Test Suites
You can create test suites attached to your metrics for pass/fail results at the dataset report level. Example tests include:

- No response has sentiment < 0
- No response exceeds 150 characters
- No more than 10% of rows fail the summary test

```python
tests = Report([
    MinValue(column="Sentiment", tests=[gte(0)]),
    MaxValue(column="Length", tests=[lte(150)]),
    CategoryCount(column="Test result", category=False, share_tests=[lte(0.1)])
])

my_test_eval = tests.run(eval_dataset, None)
my_test_eval
# my_test_eval.json()
```

This produces a Test Suite that provides clear pass/fail results, useful for automated checks and regression testing.

title: Descriptors
description: How to run evaluations for text data.
ai_section:
## Report and Tests API
For more detailed information, refer to the guides on [generating Reports](/docs/library/report) and setting [Test conditions](/docs/library/tests).

title: Overview
description: End-to-end evaluation workflow.
ai_section:
## Core Evaluation Workflow
This page shows the core eval workflow with the Evidently library and links to guides.

title: Overview
description: End-to-end evaluation workflow.
ai_section:
## Define and Run the Eval
To log the evaluation results to the Evidently Platform, first connect to [Evidently Cloud](/docs/setup/cloud) or your [local workspace](/docs/setup/self-hosting) and [create a Project](/docs/platform/projects_manage). It's optional: you can also run evals locally.

title: Overview
description: End-to-end evaluation workflow.
ai_section:
## Prepare the Input Data
Get your data in a table like a `pandas.DataFrame`. More on [data requirements](/docs/library/overview#dataset). You can also [load data](/docs/platform/datasets_workflow) from Evidently Platform, like tracing or synthetic datasets.

title: Overview
description: End-to-end evaluation workflow.
ai_section:
## Create a Dataset Object
Create a Dataset object with `DataDefinition()` that specifies column role and types. You can also use default type detection. [How to set Data Definition](/docs/library/data_definition).

```python
eval_data = Dataset.from_pandas(
    source_df,
    data_definition=DataDefinition()
)
```

title: Overview
description: End-to-end evaluation workflow.
ai_section:
## (Optional) Add Descriptors
For text evals, choose and compute row-level `descriptors`. Optionally, add row-level tests to get pass/fail for specific inputs. [How to use Descriptors](/docs/library/descriptors).

```python
eval_data.add_descriptors(descriptors=[
    TextLength("Question", alias="Length"),
    Sentiment("Answer", alias="Sentiment")
])
```

title: Overview
description: End-to-end evaluation workflow.
ai_section:
## Configure Report
For dataset-level evals (classification, data drift) or to summarize descriptors, create a `Report` with chosen `metrics` or `presets`. How to [configure Reports](/docs/library/report).

```python
report = Report([
    DataSummaryPreset()
])
```

title: Overview
description: End-to-end evaluation workflow.
ai_section:
## (Optional) Add Test Conditions
Add dataset-level Pass/Fail conditions, like to check if all texts are in < 100 symbols length. How to [configure Tests](/docs/library/tests).

```python
report = Report([
    DataSummaryPreset(),
    MaxValue(column="Length", tests=[lt(100)]),
])
```

title: Overview
description: End-to-end evaluation workflow.
ai_section:
## (Optional) Add Tags and Timestamps
Add `tags` or `metadata` to identify specific evaluation runs or datasets, or override the default `timestamp`. [How to add metadata](/docs/library/tags_metadata).

title: Overview
description: End-to-end evaluation workflow.
ai_section:
## Run the Report
To execute the eval, `run` the Report on the `Dataset` (or two).

```python
my_eval = report.run(eval_data, None)
```

title: Overview
description: End-to-end evaluation workflow.
ai_section:
## Explore the Results
* To upload to the Evidently Platform. [How to upload results](/docs/platform/evals_api).

```python
ws.add_run(project.id, my_eval, include_data=True)
```

* To view locally. [All output formats](/docs/library/output_formats).

```python
my_eval
##my_eval.json()
```

title: Overview
description: End-to-end evaluation workflow.

title: Leftovers
description: Description of your new file.
ai_section:
## Metrics Overview
This document outlines the metrics used for data quality checks and analysis, particularly in the context of exploratory data analysis and drift monitoring. It discusses how to evaluate the correlation between scores, missing values, and other key data quality indicators.

title: Leftovers
description: Description of your new file.
ai_section:
## Correlation Metrics
Correlation metrics are crucial for exploratory data analysis and monitoring drift in datasets. These metrics can help check the alignment between scores, such as LLM-based descriptors against human labels.

title: Leftovers
description: Description of your new file.
ai_section:
## Column Data Quality Metrics
Within the column data quality metrics, several key metrics are outlined, all focusing on dataset-level and column-level checks for missing values, empty columns, and category counts. 

### RowsWithMissingValuesCount()
- **Description**: Counts rows with missing values.
- **Parameters**: Optional test conditions.
- **Test Defaults**: Fails if there is at least one row with missing values or if the share differs by more than 10% when a reference is provided.

title: Leftovers
description: Description of your new file.
ai_section:
### AlmostEmptyColumnCount()
- **Description**: Counts almost empty columns (95% empty).
- **Parameters**: Optional test conditions.
- **Test Defaults**: Fails if there is at least one almost empty column or if the count is higher than in the reference.

title: Leftovers
description: Description of your new file.
ai_section:
### NewCategoriesCount()
- **Description**: Counts new categories compared to a reference.
- **Parameters**: Requires a specified column; optional test conditions.
- **Test Defaults**: Expects 0 new categories.

title: Leftovers
description: Description of your new file.
ai_section:
### MissingCategoriesCount()
- **Description**: Counts missing categories compared to a reference.
- **Parameters**: Requires a specified column; optional test conditions.
- **Test Defaults**: Expects 0 missing categories.

title: Leftovers
description: Description of your new file.
ai_section:
### MostCommonValueCount()
- **Description**: Identifies and provides the count and share of the most common value in the column.
- **Parameters**: Requires a specified column; optional test conditions.
- **Test Defaults**: Fails if the most common value share is ≥80% or differs by more than 10% from the reference.

title: Leftovers
description: Description of your new file.
ai_section:
## Drift Metrics
Drift metrics are essential for evaluating changes in the dataset over time, particularly regarding embedding and multivariate correlations.

### EmbeddingDrift()
- **Description**: Calculates data drift for embeddings.
- **Parameters**: Requires specifying embeddings and method.
- **Test Defaults**: Defaults for method apply when a reference is provided.

title: Leftovers
description: Description of your new file.
ai_section:
### MultivariateDrift()
- **Description**: Computes a single score indicating dataset drift.
- **Parameters**: Optional specification of columns and method.
- **Test Defaults**: Defaults for method apply when a reference is provided.

title: Leftovers
description: Description of your new file.
ai_section:
### DatasetCorrelations()
- **Description**: Calculates correlations between all or specified columns in the dataset using various methods (Pearson, Spearman, etc.).
- **Parameters**: Optional specification of columns and test conditions.
- **Test Defaults**: Not applicable.

title: Leftovers
description: Description of your new file.
ai_section:
### Correlation()
- **Description**: Computes the correlation between two specified columns.
- **Parameters**: Requires specification of two columns; optional method and test conditions.
- **Test Defaults**: Not applicable.

title: Leftovers

ai_section:
### CorrelationChanges()
- **Description**: Checks for significant changes in correlation strength between columns.
- **Parameters**: Optional specification of columns, method, and correlation difference threshold.
- **Test Defaults**: Fails if at least one correlation violation is detected with a reference.

## Classification Metrics
Classification metrics aim to evaluate the performance of predictive models, specifically focusing on class distributions and lift calculations.

### LabelCount()
- **Description**: Analyzes the distribution of predicted classes, useful for visualizing class balance and probability distribution.
- **Parameters**: Requires at least one visualization type; optional test conditions.
- **Test Defaults**: Not applicable.

- **Description**: Calculates the lift of predictions, which can be visualized through lift curves or tables.
- **Parameters**: Requires at least one visualization type.
- **Test Defaults**: Not applicable.

## RecSysPreset()
The **RecSysPreset()** metric provides a large preset that includes a range of recommendation system metrics. The metric result encompasses all metrics involved. For detailed information, users can refer to the [Preset page](/metrics/preset_recsys).  
**Parameters**: There are no specific parameters required for this metric.  
**Test Defaults**: The defaults are as per individual metrics.

## Personalization
The **Personalization()** metric (coming soon) calculates the personalization score at the top K recommendations, with the result being a `value`.  
**Required**: The parameter `k` must be set.  
**Optional**: Test conditions can be referenced as detailed in [Test conditions](/docs/library/tests).  
**Test Defaults**:  
- **No reference**: Tests if Personalization > 0.  
- **With reference**: Fails if Personalization differs by >10%.

description: Description of your new file.
ai_section:
## Relevant Parameters for RecSys Metrics
- `no_feedback_user: bool = False`: Specifies whether to include users who did not select any items when computing the quality metric. Default: False.
- `min_rel_score: Optional[int] = None`: Defines the minimum relevance score to consider relevant when calculating quality metrics for non-binary targets (e.g., ratings or custom scores).

title: Leftovers
description: Description of your new file.
ai_section:
## Diversity Explained
**Evidently Metric**: `Diversity`  
This metric measures the average intra-list diversity at K, reflecting the range of items within a single user's recommendation list, averaged across all users.  

### Methodology:
1. **Measure the difference between recommended items**: Calculate the Cosine distance for each pair of recommendations within the top-K in each user's list, defined by:
   $$ \text{Cosine distance} = 1 - \text{Cosine Similarity} $$
2. **Intra-list diversity**: Calculate this for each user by averaging the Cosine Distance between pairs.
3. **Overall diversity**: Average intra-list diversity across all users.

**Range**: From 0 to 2.  
**Interpretation**: Higher values indicate more varied items shown to users.  

**Requirements**: Must pass an `item_features` list to compare the similarity between different items.

title: Leftovers
description: Description of your new file.
ai_section:
## Novelty Explained
**Evidently Metric**: `Novelty`  
This metric measures the average novelty of recommendations at K, reflecting how unexpected top-K items are shown to users.

### Methodology:
1. **Measure the novelty of recommended items**: Defined by:
   $$ \text{novelty}_i = -\log_2(p_i) $$ 
   where `p` is the probability that item `i` appears in the training set.
2. **Measure by user**: Compute average item novelty at K.
3. **Overall novelty**: Average the novelty per user across all users.

**Range**: 0 to infinity.  
**Interpretation**: Higher values indicate more unusual items shown to users.

title: Leftovers
description: Description of your new file.
ai_section:
## Serendipity Explained
**Evidently Metric**: `Serendipity`  
This metric measures how unusual relevant recommendations are within K, averaged across all users.

### Methodology:
1. **Measure unexpectedness**: Using Cosine distance, compute distance between relevant recommendations and prior user interactions:
   $$ \text{serendipity}_i = \text{unexpectedness}_i \times \text{relevance}_i $$
2. **Calculate averages**: For all relevant recommendations, compute averages.

**Notes**: Higher values indicate relevant items that are unexpected for users.

title: Leftovers
description: Description of your new file.
ai_section:
## Serendipity in Recommendations
Serendipity reflects the ability of a recommender system to show relevant items that are unexpected based on user history. For instance, a user who typically enjoys comedies might be recommended a thriller and upvotes it. 

**Implemented Method**:
- Measure the **unexpectedness** of relevant recommendations using Cosine distance. The higher the distance, the greater the unexpectedness.
- The formula to calculate serendipity is:  
  $$\text{serendipity}_i = \text{unexpectedness}_i \times \text{relevance}_i$$
- Calculate average unexpectedness for each user and overall by averaging results across all users.

**Range**: 0 to 2. A value of 0 means only expected recommendations, while 2 indicates completely unexpected relevant recommendations. 

**Interpretation**: Higher values suggest a better capability of the system to pleasantly surprise users.

title: Leftovers
description: Description of your new file.
ai_section:
## Personalization of Recommendations
Personalization measures the average uniqueness of each user's recommendations in the top-K list.

**Implemented Method**:
- Compute the overlap between top-K recommended items for every two users.
- Calculate the average overlap and derive personalization as:  
  $$\text{Personalization} = 1 - \text{average overlap}$$

**Range**: 0 to 1. A value of 0 signifies identical recommendations, while 1 indicates unique recommendations for each user.

**Interpretation**: Higher values reflect more personalized recommendations.

title: Leftovers
description: Description of your new file.
ai_section:
## Average Recommendation Popularity (ARP)
ARP assesses the average popularity of recommended items, revealing any bias toward a few popular choices.

**Implementation**:
- Calculate item popularity based on training data.
- Compute average popularity for each user and then overall using the formula:  
  $$ARP = \frac{1}{|U|} \sum_{u \in U} \frac{1}{|L_u|} \sum_{i \in L_u} \phi(i)$$

**Range**: 0 to infinity. 

**Interpretation**: Higher values indicate more popular recommendations in the top-K list.

title: Leftovers
description: Description of your new file.
ai_section:
## Coverage Metric
Coverage reflects the proportion of items recommended by the system compared to all potential items.

**Implementation**:
- Compute the share of unique items recommended to users relative to the total number of unique items:  
  $$\text{Coverage} = \frac{\text{Number of unique items recommended}}{\text{Total number of unique items}}$$

**Range**: 0 to 1, where 1 means that all items have been recommended.

**Interpretation**: Higher values are generally preferable as they indicate broader representation in recommendations.

title: Leftovers
description: Description of your new file.
ai_section:
## Gini Index for Recommendation Distribution
The Gini index measures the inequality in item distribution recommendations across users.

**Implementation**:
- The Gini index is computed using the formula:  
  $$ Gini(L) = 1 - \frac{1}{|I| - 1} \sum_{k=1}^{|I|} (2k - |I| - 1) p(i_k | L)$$
- Here, *p(i|L)* is the occurrence ratio of item *i* across the recommendation lists.

**Range**: 0 to 1. A value of 0 indicates perfect equality, while 1 indicates complete inequality.

**Interpretation**: Lower values represent a more equitable distribution of recommended items among users.

title: Metric generators
description: How to generate multiple metrics at once.
ai_section:
## Generating Multiple Tests and Metrics
Sometimes you need to generate multiple column-level Tests or Metrics. To simplify this, you can use metric generator helper functions.

title: Metric generators
description: How to generate multiple metrics at once.
ai_section:
## Pre-requisites
Before using the metric generator helper functions, ensure you know how to [generate Reports](/docs/library/report).

title: Metric generators
description: How to generate multiple metrics at once.
ai_section:
## Imports
To generate toy data for this guide, you can use the following code:

```python
import pandas as pd
import numpy as np
from evidently import Dataset
from evidently import DataDefinition

np.random.seed(42)

data = {
    "Age": np.random.randint(18, 60, size=30),
    "Salary": np.random.randint(30000, 120000, size=30),
    "Department": np.random.choice(["HR", "IT", "Finance", "Marketing", "Operations"], size=30),
    "YearsExperience": np.random.randint(1, 15, size=30),  
    "EducationLevel": np.random.choice(["High School", "Bachelor", "Master", "PhD"], size=30)  
}

dummy_df = pd.DataFrame(data)

eval_data_1 = Dataset.from_pandas(
    dummy_df.iloc[:15],
    data_definition=DataDefinition()
)
eval_data_2 = Dataset.from_pandas(
    dummy_df.iloc[15:],
    data_definition=DataDefinition()
)
```

title: Metric generators
description: How to generate multiple metrics at once.
ai_section:
## Importing Necessary Libraries
For using the functionalities of the metrics and tests, import the following libraries:

```python
from evidently import Report
from evidently.metrics import *
from evidently.generators import ColumnMetricGenerator
```

title: Metric generators
description: How to generate multiple metrics at once.
ai_section:
## Metric Generators
You can apply selected metrics to your dataset using `ColumnMetricGenerator`. Here are a few examples:

**Example 1**: Apply the selected metric (`ValueDrift`) to all columns.

```python
report = Report([
    ColumnMetricGenerator(ValueDrift)
])

my_eval = report.run(eval_data_1, eval_data_2)
my_eval
```

**Example 2**: Apply `ValueDrift` only to specified columns with parameters.

```python
report = Report([
    ColumnMetricGenerator(ValueDrift, 
                          columns=["EducationLevel", "Salary"],
                          metric_kwargs={"method":"psi"}),
])

my_eval = report.run(eval_data_1, eval_data_2)
my_eval
```

**Example 3**: Apply `UniqueValueCount` only to categorical columns.

```python
report = Report([
    ColumnMetricGenerator(UniqueValueCount, 
                          column_types='cat'),
])

my_eval = report.run(eval_data_1, eval_data_2)
my_eval
```

Available column types include:
* `num` - numerical
* `cat` - categorical
* `all` - all

title: Metric generators
description: How to generate multiple metrics at once.
ai_section:
## Test Generators
You can also generate Tests using a similar approach. 

**Example**: Generate a test for all numerical columns.

```python
from evidently.future.tests import *

report = Report([
    ColumnMetricGenerator(MinValue, 
                          column_types='num',
                          metric_kwargs={"tests":[gt(0)]}), 
])

my_eval = report.run(eval_data_1, eval_data_2)
my_eval
```

This example applies the minimum value test to all numerical columns, checking that they are above 0.

title: Output formats
description: How to export the evaluation results.
ai_section:
## Exporting Reports
You can view or export Reports in multiple formats.

**Pre-requisites**:
* You know how to [generate Reports](/docs/library/report).

title: Output formats
description: How to export the evaluation results.
ai_section:
## Log to Workspace
You can save the computed Report in Evidently Cloud or your local workspace.

```python
ws.add_run(project.id, my_eval, include_data=False)
```

<Info>
  **Uploading evals**. Check Quickstart examples [for ML](/quickstart_ml) or [for LLM](/quickstart_llm) for a full workflow.
</Info>

title: Output formats
description: How to export the evaluation results.
ai_section:
## View in Jupyter notebook
You can directly render the visual summary of evaluation results in interactive Python environments like Jupyter notebook or Colab.

After running the Report, simply call the resulting Python object:

```python
my_report
```

This will render the HTML object directly in the notebook cell.

title: Output formats
description: How to export the evaluation results.
ai_section:
## HTML Export
You can also save this interactive visual Report as an HTML file to open in a browser:

```python
my_report.save_html(“file.html”)
```

This option is useful for sharing Reports with others or if you're working in a Python environment that doesn’t display interactive visuals.

title: Output formats
description: How to export the evaluation results.
ai_section:
## JSON Format
You can get the results of the calculation as a JSON. It is useful for storing and exporting results elsewhere.

To view the JSON in Python:

```python
my_report.json()
```

To save the JSON as a separate file:

```python
my_report.save_json("file.json")
```

title: Output formats
description: How to export the evaluation results.
ai_section:
## Python Dictionary Output
You can get the output as a Python dictionary. This format is convenient for automated evaluations in data or ML pipelines, allowing you to transform the output or extract specific values.

To get the dictionary:

```python
my_report.dict()
```

title: Introduction
description: Core concepts and components of the Evidently Python library.
ai_section:
## Introduction to Evidently Python Library
The Evidently Python library is an open-source tool designed to evaluate, test, and monitor the quality of AI systems, from experimentation to production. It can be used independently or as part of the Monitoring Platform (self-hosted or Evidently Cloud).

title: Introduction
description: Core concepts and components of the Evidently Python library.
ai_section:
## Core Workflows of Evidently
Evidently covers four core workflows that can be used together or standalone:
1. AI/ML Evaluations
2. Synthetic Data Generation
3. Prompt Optimization
4. Tracking and Visualization UI

title: Introduction
description: Core concepts and components of the Evidently Python library.
ai_section:
## AI/ML Evaluations
**TL;DR**: The library provides numerous AI/ML/data metrics out of the box, exportable as scores or visual reports. 

Evidently runs evaluations on AI system inputs and outputs using over 100 built-in metrics and checks, including both metrics for predictive ML tasks and generative LLM outputs.

title: Introduction
description: Core concepts and components of the Evidently Python library.
ai_section:
## Evaluation Metrics
The library supports various types of built-in checks, such as:
- **Text qualities**: Length, sentiment, special symbols.
- **LLM output quality**: Semantic similarity, relevance.
- **Data quality**: Missing values, duplicates.
- **Data drift**: 20+ tests to detect distribution drift.
- **Classification**: Accuracy, precision, recall.
- **Regression**: MAE, RMSE, error distributions.
- **Ranking**: NDCG, MAP, MRR.

title: Introduction
description: Core concepts and components of the Evidently Python library.
ai_section:
## Export Options for Evaluations
Evidently allows evaluation results to be exported in multiple formats:
- JSON or Python dictionary for scores.
- DataFrame with metrics or attached scores.
- Visual reports in Jupyter, Colab, or as HTML.
- Upload functionality to the Evidently Platform for long-term tracking.

title: Introduction
description: Core concepts and components of the Evidently Python library.
ai_section:
## Synthetic Data Generation
**TL;DR**: A configuration for structured synthetic data generation using LLMs is now available.

Evidently helps generate synthetic test datasets, useful for creating RAG-style question-answer pairs and other test inputs.

title: Introduction
description: Core concepts and components of the Evidently Python library.
ai_section:
## Prompt Optimization
**TL;DR**: The library includes tools for automated prompt writing using labeled or annotated data.

Evidently provides features for scoring prompt variations based on a target dataset or user feedback, also generating LLM judge prompts for custom evaluations.

title: Introduction
description: Core concepts and components of the Evidently Python library.
ai_section:
## Tracking and Visualization UI
**TL;DR**: The Evidently library includes a minimal UI to store and track evaluation results over time.

This UI allows for storing, comparing, and visualizing multiple evaluations, offering a historical perspective against previous results.

title: Introduction
description: Core concepts and components of the Evidently Python library.
ai_section:
## Core Evaluation Concepts
To run an evaluation, prepare data as a pandas DataFrame. This data can include various columns like numerical, categorical, and text. 

Examples include:
- LLM logs with questions and answers.
- Data tables for ML model performance.
- Classification and regression logs.

title: Introduction
description: Core concepts and components of the Evidently Python library.
ai_section:
## Dataset Preparation
To evaluate, create an Evidently `Dataset` object from your prepared data. This captures metadata for proper processing and may require specific columns or types.

title: Introduction
description: Core concepts and components of the Evidently Python library.
ai_section:
## Using Multiple Datasets
You can prepare a second dataset to compare against the current dataset for:
- Side-by-side comparisons.
- Data drift detection.
- Simplifying test setups with automatic range generation from the reference dataset.

title: Introduction
description: Core concepts and components of the Evidently Python library.
ai_section:
## Descriptors for Text Data
To evaluate text data and LLM outputs, utilize `Descriptors`, which are row-level scores or labels for analysis. Descriptors enable a more granular evaluation of text-related data.

title: Introduction
description: Core concepts and components of the Evidently Python library.
ai_section:
## Test Setup Simplification
The test setup can be simplified by automatically generating test conditions, such as min-max ranges, from the reference dataset, eliminating the need for manual configuration.

title: Introduction
description: Core concepts and components of the Evidently Python library.
ai_section:
## Data Sampling
For large datasets, evaluations can be time-consuming, depending on the evaluation's complexity, dataset size, and infrastructure. When computation is slow, using sampling methods like random or stratified sampling can be more efficient.

title: Introduction
description: Core concepts and components of the Evidently Python library.
ai_section:
## Descriptors
Descriptors are row-level scores or labels assessing specific qualities of text data. They differ from metrics, which evaluate an entire dataset. Descriptors can range from basic metrics like `TextLength` to more complex checks such as `LLMEval`. You can create custom checks and use built-in descriptors to return results in numerical, categorical, or text formats.

title: Introduction
description: Core concepts and components of the Evidently Python library.
ai_section:
## Reports
A Report structures evaluations on datasets or columns. You can generate Reports after obtaining descriptors to summarize text descriptors, analyze data quality, or evaluate AI performance. Each Report visualizes a set of Metrics and conditional Tests, and you can use Presets to simplify configuration.

title: Introduction
description: Core concepts and components of the Evidently Python library.
ai_section:
## Metric Presets
Metric Presets are pre-configured evaluation templates allowing multiple related Metrics to be computed via a single command. They cover various scenarios, including exploratory data analysis and AI quality assessments.

title: Introduction
description: Core concepts and components of the Evidently Python library.
ai_section:
## Metrics
Metrics are individual components within Presets. You can create custom Reports by selecting desired Metrics and include both built-in and custom options. Built-in Metrics range from simple statistics to complex algorithm evaluations.

title: Introduction
description: Core concepts and components of the Evidently Python library.
ai_section:
## Test Suites
Test Suites enable you to run conditional checks against expected outcomes, allowing for automated validation of results. Each Test computes a value, checks against a condition, and reports a pass/fail outcome.

title: Introduction
description: Core concepts and components of the Evidently Python library.
ai_section:
## Test Conditions
You can establish Test conditions using manual or automatic setups. Manual setups involve adding thresholds directly to Metrics, while automatic setups utilize defaults or heuristics that adjust relative to a reference dataset.

title: Introduction
description: Core concepts and components of the Evidently Python library.
ai_section:
## Test Presets
Test Presets enable quick setup by adding predefined Tests to Reports based on Metric Presets. These Tests check for quality issues, such as missing values or duplicates, employing either static or reference-inferred conditions.

title: Introduction
description: Core concepts and components of the Evidently Python library.
ai_section:
## Building Your Workflow
You can utilize Reports and Test Suites independently for ad-hoc checks, experiments, and debugging. Alternatively, they can be integrated into production workflows for monitoring and validation purposes using tools like Airflow.

title: Introduction
description: Core concepts and components of the Evidently Python library.
ai_section:
## Platform Deployment Options
Evidently provides flexibility in deployment, allowing you to self-host the open-source version or opt for the recommended Evidently Cloud, which includes additional features such as synthetic data and test generation.

description: [NEW] Automated prompt optimization.
ai_section:

ai_section:
## Example Notebooks
Here are some example notebooks that illustrate different prompt optimization techniques for LLM judges:

title: Report
description: How to generate Report.
ai_section:
## Introduction to Reports
Reports perform evaluations on the Dataset level and/or summarize results of the row-level evaluations. For a general introduction, check [Core Concepts](/docs/library/overview).

**Pre-requisites**:
- You [installed Evidently](/docs/setup/installation).
- You created a Dataset with the [Data Definition](/docs/library/data_definition).
- (Optional) for text data, you added Descriptors.

<Note>
For a quick end-to-end example of generating Reports, check the Quickstart [for ML](/quickstart_ml) or [LLM](/quickstart_llm).
</Note>

title: Report
description: How to generate Report.
ai_section:
## Imports
Import the Metrics and Presets you plan to use.

```python
from evidently import Report
from evidently.metrics import *
from evidently.presets import *
```

You can use Metric Presets, which are pre-built Reports that work out of the box, or create a custom Report selecting Metrics one by one.

title: Report
description: How to generate Report.
ai_section:
## Using Presets
<Tip>
**Available Presets**. Check available evals in the [Reference table](/metrics/all_metrics).
</Tip>

To generate a template Report, simply pass the selected Preset to the Report and run it over your data. 

### Single dataset
To generate the Data Summary Report for a single dataset:

```python
report = Report([
    DataSummaryPreset()
])

my_eval = report.run(eval_data_1, None)
my_eval
#my_eval.json
```

After you `run` the Report, the resulting `my_eval` contains the computed values for each metric, along with associated metadata and visualizations.

<Note>
You can render the results in Python, export as HTML, JSON or Python dictionary or upload to the Evidently platform. Check more in [output formats](/docs/library/output_formats).
</Note>

### Two datasets
To generate reports like Data Drift that need two datasets, pass the second one as a reference:

```python
report = Report([
    DataDriftPreset()
])

my_eval = report.run(eval_data_1, eval_data_2)
my_eval
#my_eval.json
```

### Combine Presets
You can also include multiple Presets in the same Report:

```python
report = Report([
    DataDriftPreset(), 
    DataSummaryPreset()
])

my_eval = report.run(eval_data_1, eval_data_2)
my_eval
#my_eval.json
```

title: Report
description: How to generate Report.
ai_section:
## Custom Report Creation
<Tip>
**Available Metrics and parameters**. Check available evals in the [Reference table](/metrics/all_metrics).
</Tip>

### Choose Metrics
To create a custom Report, list the Metrics one by one. You can combine both dataset-level and column-level Metrics:

```python
report = Report([
    ColumnCount(), 
    ValueStats(column="target")
])

my_eval = report.run(eval_data_1, None)
my_eval
#my_eval.json
```

### Metric Parameters
Metrics can have optional or required parameters.

To calculate the Precision at K for a ranking task, you must pass the `k` parameter (Required):

```python
report = Report([
   PrecisionTopK(k=10)
])
```

title: Report
description: How to generate Report.
ai_section:
## Comparing Results
If you computed multiple snapshots, you can quickly compare the resulting metrics side-by-side in a dataframe:

```python
from evidently import compare

compare_dataframe = compare(my_eval_1, my_eval_2, my_eval_3)
```

title: Report
description: How to generate Report.
ai_section:
## Grouping by Categories
You can calculate metrics separately for different groups in your data using a column with categories. Use the `GroupBy` metric as shown below.

### Example
This will compute the maximum value of salaries by each label in the "Department" column:

```python
from evidently.metrics.group_by import GroupBy

report = Report([
    GroupBy(MaxValue(column="Salary"), "Department"),
])
my_eval = report.run(data, None)
my_eval.dict()
```

Note: You cannot use auto-generated Test conditions when you use GroupBy.

title: Report
description: How to generate Report.
ai_section:
## What's Next?
You can also add conditions to Metrics: check the [Tests guide](/docs/library/tests).

title: Synthetic data generation
description: [NEW] Code-first synthetic data generation.
ai_section:
## Generating Synthetic Test Data
You can generate synthetic test data from the RAG knowledge base or by using a simple configuration.

title: Synthetic data generation
description: [NEW] Code-first synthetic data generation.
ai_section:
## Documentation Availability
More detailed documentation on synthetic test data generation will be available soon.

title: Synthetic data generation
description: [NEW] Code-first synthetic data generation.
