## Example Notebooks
An example notebook for synthetic data generation can be found at: [code example](https://github.com/evidentlyai/evidently/blob/main/examples/cookbook/datagen.ipynb).

title: Add tags and metadata
description: How to add metadata to evaluations.
ai_section:
## Adding Timestamps to Reports
Each Report run has a single timestamp. By default, Evidently assigns `datetime.now()` as the run time based on the user's time zone. You can also specify a custom timestamp by passing it to the `run()` method, allowing for asynchronous logging or backdating of Reports to the relevant time period.

```python
from datetime import datetime

my_eval_4 = report.run(eval_data_1,
                       eval_data_2,
                       timestamp=datetime(2024, 1, 29))
```

title: Add tags and metadata
description: How to add metadata to evaluations.
ai_section:
## Adding Tags and Metadata to Reports
You can add `tags` and `metadata` to Reports for improved searchability and filtering. Tags enable visualization of data subsets on monitoring Panels, marking evaluations by various criteria such as model version or user segment.

### Custom Tags
Pass any custom Tags as a list when creating a Report:

```python
report = Report([
    ClassificationPreset()
],
tags=["classification", "production"])
```

### Custom Metadata
Pass metadata as a Python dictionary in key:value pairs:

```python
report = Report([
    ClassificationPreset()
],
metadata = {
    "deployment": "shadow",
    "status": "production",
})
```

### Default Metadata
Use built-in metadata fields like `model_id`, `reference_id`, `batch_size`, and `dataset_id`:

```python
report = Report([
    ClassificationPreset()
],
  model_id="model_id",
  reference_id="reference_id",
  batch_size="batch_size",
  dataset_id="dataset_id"
)
```

### Adding Tags to Individual Runs
You can tag individual Report runs, which is useful for experiments with varying prompts or hyperparameters:

```python
my_eval = report.run(eval_data_1, eval_data_2, tags=["prompt_v1", "claude"])
```

title: Tests
description: How to run conditional checks.
ai_section:
## Overview of Tests
Tests let you validate specific conditions and get Pass/Fail results on the dataset level. Tests are an add-on to the Report and appear in a separate tab.

**Pre-requisites**:
* You know how to [generate Reports and select Metrics](/docs/library/report).

**Note**: For a quick end-to-end example of generating Tests, check the Quickstart [for ML](/quickstart_ml) or [LLM](/quickstart_llm).

title: Tests
description: How to run conditional checks.
ai_section:
## Imports
To use Tests, import the following modules:

```python
from evidently import Report
from evidently.metrics import *
from evidently.presets import *
from evidently.tests import *
```

title: Tests
description: How to run conditional checks.
ai_section:
## Auto-generated Conditions
There are 3 ways to run conditional checks:

* **Tests Presets**: Get a suite of pre-selected Tests with auto-generated conditions. 
* **Tests with Defaults**: Pick Tests one by one, with auto-generated conditions.
* **Custom Tests**: Choose all Tests and set conditions manually.

title: Tests
description: How to run conditional checks.
ai_section:
### Test Presets
Test Presets automatically generate a set of Tests to evaluate your data or AI system. Each Report Preset has this option. 

Enable it by setting `include_tests=True` on the Report level. (Default: False).

```python
report = Report([
    DataSummaryPreset(),
],
include_tests=True)
```

For example, while the `DataSummaryPreset()` Report simply shows descriptive stats of your data, adding the Tests will additionally run multiple checks on data quality and expected column statistics.

**Using Reference**: Tests compare the new data against a reference dataset.

```Python
my_eval = report.run(eval_data_1, eval_data_2) # eval_data_2 is reference
```

**Using Heuristics**: Without a reference, Tests use predefined rules.

```Python
my_eval = report.run(eval_data_1, None) # no reference data
```

**Info**: To check Test defaults, consult the [All Metrics](/metrics/all_metrics) reference table.

title: Tests
description: How to run conditional checks.
ai_section:
### Individual Tests with Defaults
You can select specific Tests while still using default conditions.

**Select Tests**: List individual Metrics and use the `include_Tests` option.

```Python
report = Report([
    MissingValueCount(column="Age"),
    MinValue(column="Age"),
], 
include_tests=True)
```

**Exclude Some Tests**: To prevent Test generation for certain Metrics/Presets, set the list of `tests` to `None` or leave it empty.

```Python
report = Report([
    MissingValueCount(column="Age", tests=[]),
    MinValue(column="Age"),
], 
include_tests=True)
```

title: Tests
description: How to run conditional checks.
ai_section:
## Custom Test Conditions
You can define specific pass/fail conditions for each Test.

**Setting Conditions**: Define a list of `tests` for each Metric you want to validate.

```Python
report = Report([
    MissingValueCount(column="Age", tests=[eq(0)]),
    MinValue(column="Age", tests=[gte(18)]),
])
```

**Info**: Sometimes, you may need to use other parameters to set test conditions. The `tests` parameter applies when a metric returns a single value.

title: Tests
description: How to run conditional checks.
ai_section:
### Test Parameters
Here are the conditions you can set:

| Condition      | Explanation                                       | Example                                                |
|

title: Tests
description: How to run conditional checks.

title: Tests
description: How to run conditional checks.

title: Tests
description: How to run conditional checks.
ai_section:
|
| `eq(val)`      | equal to                                         | `MinValue(column="Age", tests=[eq(18)])`             |
| `not_eq(val)`  | not equal                                       | `MinValue(column="Age", tests=[not_eq(18)])`         |
| `gt(val)`      | greater than                                    | `MinValue(column="Age", tests=[gt(18)])`             |
| `gte(val)`     | greater than or equal                           | `MinValue(column="Age", tests=[gte(18)])`            |
| `lt(val)`      | less than                                       | `MinValue(column="Age", tests=[lt(18)])`             |
| `lte(val)`     | less than or equal                              | `MinValue(column="Age", tests=[lte(18)])`            |
| `is_in: list`  | `test_result ==` one of the values              | `MinValue(column="Age", tests=[is_in([18, 21, 30])])`  |
| `not_in: list` | `test_result !=` any of the values              | `MinValue(column="Age", tests=[not_in([16, 17, 18])])` |

**Info**: To check available parameters, consult the [All Metrics](/metrics/all_metrics) reference table.

title: Tests
description: How to run conditional checks.
ai_section:
### Combining Custom and Default Conditions
You can use both default and custom conditions across the Report.

```Python
report = Report([
    RowCount(tests=[gt(10)]),
    MissingValueCount(column="Age"),
],
include_tests=True) 
```

You can also add multiple checks to the same Metric.

```python
report = Report([
    MinValue(column="Age", tests=[gte(17), lte(19)]),
])
```

title: Tests
description: How to run conditional checks.
ai_section:
### Tests Relative to Reference
**Testing Against Reference**: Define conditions relative to the reference values.

```python
report = Report([
   RowCount(tests=[gte(Reference(relative=0.1))]),
])
```

You can also define the absolute difference from reference.

```python
report = Report([
   RowCount(tests=[gte(Reference(absolute=5))]),
])
```

title: Tests
description: How to run conditional checks.
ai_section:
### Setting Test Criticality
By default, failed Tests return Fail. To get a Warning instead, set `is_critical=False`. 

```python
report = Report([
    MissingValueCount(column="Age", share_tests=[eq(0, is_critical=False)]),
])
```

This helps manage alert fatigue. For layered conditions, you can also set:

```python
report = Report([
    MissingValueCount(column="Age", 
                      share_tests=[eq(0, is_critical=False), 
                                   lte(0.1, is_critical=True)]),
])
```

title: Alerts
description: How to set up alerts.
ai_section:
## Built-in Alerting Overview
Built-in alerting is a Pro feature available in the **Evidently Cloud** and **Evidently Enterprise**.

title: Alerts
description: How to set up alerts.
ai_section:
## How to Enable Alerts
To enable alerts, open the Project and navigate to the "Alerts" in the left menu. You must set:

* A notification channel.
* An alert condition.

title: Alerts
description: How to set up alerts.
ai_section:
## Notification Channels
You can choose between the following options for notification channels:

* **Email**: Add email addresses to send alerts to.
* **Slack**: Add a Slack webhook.
* **Discord**: Add a Discord webhook.

title: Alerts
description: How to set up alerts.
ai_section:
## Alert Conditions
There are two types of alert conditions you can set:

### Failed Tests
If you use Tests (conditional checks) in your Project, you can tie alerting to the failed Tests in a Test Suite. Toggle this option on the Alerts page. Evidently will set an alert to the defined channel if any of the Tests fail.

<Tip>
  **How to avoid alert fatigue?** Use the `is_critical` parameter to mark non-critical Tests as Warnings. Setting it to `False` prevents alerts for those checks even if they fail.
</Tip>

title: Alerts
description: How to set up alerts.
ai_section:
### Custom Conditions
You can also set alerts on individual Metric values. For example, you can generate Alerts when the share of drifting features is above a certain threshold. Click on the plus sign below the “Add new Metric alert” and follow the prompts to set an alert condition.

title: Add dashboard panels (API)
description: How to design your Dashboard with custom Panels.
ai_section:
## Adding Panels via Python API
You can add Panels in the user interface or using the Python API. This section describes how to use the Python API for adding panels to your dashboard. 

### Pre-requisites
To get started, you must first connect to [Evidently Cloud](/docs/setup/cloud) and [create a Project](/docs/platform/projects_manage).

title: Add dashboard panels (API)
description: How to design your Dashboard with custom Panels.
ai_section:
## Dashboard Management
Dashboards as code are available in Evidently OSS, Cloud, and Enterprise.

### Adding Tabs
To add a new Tab, use the following command:
```python
project.dashboard.add_tab("Another Tab")
```
You can also create a new Tab while adding a Panel. If the destination Tab doesn’t exist, it will be created; if it does, the Panel will be added below existing ones.

### Deleting Tabs
To delete a Tab, execute:
```python
project.dashboard.delete_tab("Another Tab")
```

### Deleting Panels
To delete a specific Panel, use:
```python
project.dashboard.delete_panel("Dashboard title", "My new tab")
```
(Note: List the Panel name first, then the Tab name.)

### Clearing the Dashboard
To delete all Tabs and Panels on the Dashboard, use:
```python
project.dashboard.clear_dashboard()
```
Note: This does **not** delete the underlying Reports or dataset; it only clears the Panels.

title: Add dashboard panels (API)
description: How to design your Dashboard with custom Panels.
ai_section:
## Adding Different Types of Panels
### Text Panels
Text-only panels are perfect for titles. To add a text panel:
```python
project.dashboard.add_panel(
    DashboardPanelPlot(
        title="Dashboard title",
        size="full", 
        values=[], #leave empty
        plot_params={"plot_type": "text"},
    ),
    tab="My new tab", #will create a Tab if there is no Tab with this name
)
```

### Counter Panels
Counter panels display a value with optional supporting text. Here’s how to add counters for the `RowCount` metric with different aggregations:
```python
# Sum
project.dashboard.add_panel(
    DashboardPanelPlot(
        title="Row count",
        subtitle="Total number of evaluations over time.",
        size="half",
        values=[PanelMetric(legend="Row count", metric="RowCount")],
        plot_params={"plot_type": "counter", "aggregation": "sum"},
    ),
    tab="My tab",
)

# Average
project.dashboard.add_panel(
    DashboardPanelPlot(
        title="Row count",
        subtitle="Average number of evaluations per Report.",
        size="half",
        values=[PanelMetric(legend="Row count", metric="RowCount")],
        plot_params={"plot_type": "counter", "aggregation": "avg"},
    ),
    tab="My tab",
)

# Last
project.dashboard.add_panel(
    DashboardPanelPlot(
        title="Row count",
        subtitle="Latest number of evaluations.",
        size="half",
        values=[PanelMetric(legend="Row count", metric="RowCount")],
        plot_params={"plot_type": "counter", "aggregation": "last"},
    ),
    tab="My tab",
)
```

### Pie Charts
To add pie charts, you can use the aggregation parameters similar to counters:
```python
project.dashboard.add_panel(
    DashboardPanelPlot(
        title="Row count",
        subtitle="Total number of evaluations over time.",
        size="half",
        values=[PanelMetric(legend="Row count", metric="RowCount")],
        plot_params={"plot_type": "pie", "aggregation": "sum"},
    ),
    tab="My tab",
)
```

### Plots
Panels can also display values as bar or line plots. To add time series panels for the `RowCount` metric:
```python
# line chart
project.dashboard.add_panel(
    DashboardPanelPlot(
        title="Row count",
        subtitle="Number of evaluations over time.",
        size="half",
        values=[
            PanelMetric(
                legend="row count",
                metric="RowCount",
            ),
        ],
        plot_params={"plot_type": "line"},
    ),
    tab="My tab",
)

# bar chart
project.dashboard.add_panel(
    DashboardPanelPlot(
        title="Row count",
        subtitle="Number of evaluations over time.",
        size="half",
        values=[
            PanelMetric(
                legend="row count",
                metric="RowCount",
            ),
        ],
        plot_params={"plot_type": "bar", "is_stacked": False}, 
    ),
    tab="My tab",
)
```

### Multiple Values in a Single Panel
A Panel can show multiple values. For example, this adds multiple lines on a Line chart:
```python
project.dashboard.add_panel(
    DashboardPanelPlot(
        title="Text Length",
        subtitle="Text length stats (symbols).",
        size="full",
        values=[
            PanelMetric(legend="max", metric="MaxValue", metric_labels={"column": "length"}),
            PanelMetric(legend="mean", metric="MeanValue", metric_labels={"column": "length"}),
            PanelMetric(legend="min", metric="MinValue", metric_labels={"column": "length"}),
        ]
    )
)
```

title: Add dashboard panels (API)
description: How to design your Dashboard with custom Panels.
ai_section:
## Dashboard Panel Options
A summary of all parameters for Panels is as follows:

| Parameter              | Type   | Required | Default  | Description                                                                               |
|

title: Add dashboard panels (API)
description: How to design your Dashboard with custom Panels.

title: Add dashboard panels (API)
description: How to design your Dashboard with custom Panels.

title: Add dashboard panels (API)
description: How to design your Dashboard with custom Panels.

title: Add dashboard panels (API)
description: How to design your Dashboard with custom Panels.
ai_section:
-- |
| `title`                | `str`  | ❌        | `None`   | Title of the panel.                                                                       |
| `description`          | `str`  | ❌        | `None`   | Optional panel description shown as a subtitle.                                           |
| `size`                 | `str`  | ❌        | `"full"` | Panel size: `"full"` (100% width) or `"half"` (50%).                                      |
| `values`               | `list` | ✅        | —        | List of `PanelMetric` objects to display.                                                 |
| `tab`                  | `str`  | ❌        | `None`   | Dashboard tab name. If not set, defaults to the first tab or creates a new "General" tab. |
| `create_if_not_exists` | `bool` | ❌        | `True`   | If `True`, creates the tab if it doesn't exist. Throws exception if `False`.              |
| `plot_params`          | `dict` | ❌        | `{}`     | Panel visualization settings like `"plot_type"`: `"text"`, `"line"`, `"counter"`.         |

title: Add dashboard panels (API)
description: How to design your Dashboard with custom Panels.
ai_section:
## Configuring Panel Values
### Metric
To define which value the Panel displays, reference the name of the corresponding Evidently Metric. This metric must be present in the Reports logged to your Project.

- **Dataset-level Metrics**: Pass the Metric name directly to `PanelMetric`, e.g., `"RowCount"`.
  
Example:
```python
project.dashboard.add_panel(
    DashboardPanelPlot(
        title="Row count",
        subtitle="Number of evaluations over time.",
        size="half",
        values=[
            PanelMetric(
                legend="Row count",
                metric="RowCount",
            ),
        ],
        plot_params={"plot_type": "line"},
    ),
    tab="My tab",
)
```

### Presets
When logging Reports using a Preset, refer to the specific metric inside it, such as `Accuracy` or `Recall`.

**Need help finding metric names?** See the [All Metrics Reference Table](/metrics/all_metrics) for a full list of Metrics.

title: Add dashboard panels (API)
description: How to design your Dashboard with custom Panels.
ai_section:
## Metric Labels
Some Metrics require additional context, especially when they:

- Operate at the column level
- Return multiple values (metric results)
- Have user-defined custom parameters

These cases require you to use `metric_labels`.

**Example**: To plot the share of categories inside the "Denials" column:
```python
project.dashboard.add_panel(
    DashboardPanelPlot(
        title="Denials",
        subtitle="Number of denials.",
        size="half",
        values=[
            PanelMetric(
                legend="""{{label}}""",
                metric="UniqueValueCount",
                metric_labels={"column": "denials", "value_type": "share"} 
            ),
        ],
        plot_params={"plot_type": "bar", "is_stacked": True},
    ),
    tab="My tab",
)
```

### Column / Descriptor
For metrics that operate at the column level, use the `column` label to specify the descriptor it refers to.

**Example**: To plot the min value from the "Text Length" column:
```python
values=[
    PanelMetric(
        legend="Min text length",
        metric="MinValue",
        metric_labels={"column": "TextLength"},
    )
]
```

### Value Type
Most evidential Metrics return a single `value`. Some metrics return multiple results, in which case you must specify which value to plot using the `value_type` key.

**Example**:
```python
values = [
    PanelMetric(
        legend="Share",
        metric="DriftedColumnsCount", 
        metric_labels={"value_type": "share"}
    )
]
```

**Metrics with Extra Parameters**: If a metric has configurable options, these must also be included accordingly.

title: Add dashboard panels (API)
description: How to design your Dashboard with custom Panels.
ai_section:
## Helpful Resources
**How to verify the metric result for a specific metric?**
- Look up expected outputs in the [All Metrics Table](/metrics/all_metrics).
- Generate a Report with the target `metric` and inspect its structure via `report.dict()` or `report.json()`.

title: Add dashboard panels (API)
description: How to design your Dashboard with custom Panels.
ai_section:
## Metric Results Explained
Some metrics produce multiple results, such as:

- `CategoryCount`: returns both `share` and `count`
- `MAE`: returns both `mean` and `std`

To specify which value you want, use the `value_type` key, for example: `{"value_type": "share"}`.

```python
values = [
    PanelMetric(
        legend="Share",
        metric="DriftedColumnsCount",  # <- metric from Data Drift Preset that returns `count` or `share` of drifting columns
        metric_labels={"value_type": "share"}  # <- plot relative share
    ),
]
```

title: Add dashboard panels (API)
description: How to design your Dashboard with custom Panels.
ai_section:
## Verifying Metric Results
**How to verify the metric result for a specific metric?**

- Look up the expected outputs in the [All Metrics Table](/metrics/all_metrics).
- Generate a report with the target `metric` and inspect its structure via `report.dict()` or `report.json()`.

title: Add dashboard panels (API)
description: How to design your Dashboard with custom Panels.
ai_section:
## Metrics with Extra Parameters
For metrics that have configurable options (like drift method), you must also include those in `metric_labels`.

title: Add dashboard panels (API)
description: How to design your Dashboard with custom Panels.
ai_section:
## PanelMetric Options
A summary of all parameters for `PanelMetric`:

| Parameter       | Type   | Required | Default | Description                                                                      |
|

title: Add dashboard panels (API)
description: How to design your Dashboard with custom Panels.
ai_section:
-- |
| `legend`        | `str`  | ❌        | `None`  | Legend name in the panel. If `None`, one is auto-generated.                     |
| `tags`          | `list` | ❌        | `[]`    | Optional tags to select values from a subset of Reports in the Project.         |
| `metadata`      | `dict` | ❌        | `{}`    | Optional metadata to select values from a subset of Reports in the Project.     |
| `metric`        | `str`  | ✅        | —       | Metric name (e.g., `"RowCount"`).                                              |
| `metric_labels` | `dict` | ❌        | `{}`    | Parameters like `column` names (applies to descriptors too) or `value_type`.   |

title: Add dashboard panels (UI)
description: How to design your Dashboard with custom Panels.
ai_section:
## Dashboards Overview
Dashboards let you create Panels to visualize evaluation results over time. To populate these panels, you must first add Reports with evaluation results to the Project. No-code Dashboards are available in the Evidently Cloud and Enterprise.

title: Add dashboard panels (UI)
description: How to design your Dashboard with custom Panels.
ai_section:
## Adding Tabs
By default, new Panels appear on a single Dashboard. You can add multiple Tabs to organize them.

**To add a Tab**:

- Enter "Edit" mode on the Dashboard (top right corner).
- Click the plus sign with "add Tab" on the left.
- To create a custom Tab, select "empty" and enter a name.

Pre-built Tabs are available as dashboard templates with preset Panel combinations. These rely on having related Metrics within the Project, and if the necessary data is not available, Panels will appear empty until Reports containing those Metrics are added.

Available Tabs include:
| Template    | Description                                                                                                                    | Data source                                                                 |
|

title: Add dashboard panels (UI)
description: How to design your Dashboard with custom Panels.

title: Add dashboard panels (UI)
description: How to design your Dashboard with custom Panels.

title: Add dashboard panels (UI)
description: How to design your Dashboard with custom Panels.
ai_section:
|
| **Columns** | Shows the results of text evaluations over time OR plots column distributions over time for categorical and numerical columns. | `TextEvals()`, `DataSummaryPreset()` or `ValueStats()` for individual columns. |

**To delete a Tab**: enter "Edit" mode, choose "edit Tabs" next to Tab names, and select the Tab to delete.

title: Add dashboard panels (UI)
description: How to design your Dashboard with custom Panels.
ai_section:
## Adding Panels
You can add any number of Panels to your Dashboard, including text panels, counters, pie charts, line plots, and bar plots (grouped and stacked). When you create a Panel, you pull the corresponding value from multiple Reports and display it over time or using specified aggregation methods (sum, average, last).

**How to add a Panel:**

- Enter "Edit" mode on the Dashboard (top right corner).
- Click on the "Add Panel" button next to it.
- Follow the prompts to configure the panel.
- Use the preview to review your setup.
- Click "Save" and select the Tab where you want to add the Panel.

**Key Configuration Options**:
- **Select Metrics**: Ensure you choose the correct Metric name that matches the name logged inside the Reports.
- **Filter by Tag**: Use the "From" field to filter metrics by Tags, which must be attached to the Reports.
- **Filter by Metric label**: Specify further keys like Column and Value type for Metrics that return both.
- **Set Legend and Panel Type**: Modify legend display and specify the plot type and aggregation level.

title: Add dashboard panels (UI)
description: How to design your Dashboard with custom Panels.
ai_section:
## Deleting/Editing Panels
To delete or edit a Panel, enter Edit mode and hover over a specific Panel to choose an action.

title: Overview
description: Introduction to Dashboard.
ai_section:
## What is a Dashboard?
A Dashboard provides a clear view of your AI application performance. You can use it:

- to track evaluation results across multiple experiments;
- to track live production quality over time.

Each Project has its own Dashboard. It's empty at first. To populate it, you need to run an evaluation and **save at least one Report** to the Project. You can then choose values from Reports to plot.

title: Overview
description: Introduction to Dashboard.
ai_section:
## Dashboard Tabs
Multiple Tabs are available in **Evidently Cloud** and **Evidently Enterprise**. You can logically organize Panels within the same Dashboard into different Tabs.

title: Overview
description: Introduction to Dashboard.
ai_section:
## Dashboard Panels
A Panel is a visual element in the Dashboard that displays specified values in a single widget. Panels can be counters, line plots, bar plots, etc. You can add multiple Panels to the Dashboard and customize their type and values shown.

You can add Panels in two ways:
- Using the Python API – define your Dashboard as code.
- Through the UI – add Panels directly from the interface (Cloud and Enterprise only).

To create a Panel, you need to specify:
- Value – choose an individual metric to plot.
- Parameters – such as title, panel type, and size.
- Tags (optional) – use to filter and visualize subsets of your data.

title: Overview
description: Introduction to Dashboard.
ai_section:
## From Dashboard to Reports
By clicking on any individual value on the Dashboard, you can open the associated Report and source Dataset for further debugging.

title: Overview
description: Introduction to Dashboard.
ai_section:
## Data Source
Dashboards rely on having **Reports** in the Project as a data source. 

When adding a Panel, you select a **Metric**, and Evidently pulls the corresponding value(s) from all Reports in the Project to plot them.

For example, if you log multiple Data Drift Reports (each includes the `DriftedColumnsCount` for the corresponding batch), you can plot how this Metric value changes over time.

The Panel time resolution depends on logged Report frequency. For instance, if you log Reports daily, you'll see values at daily granularity.

You can use **Tags** to filter data from specific Reports. For example, you can plot the accuracy of Model A and Model B on separate Panels. To achieve this, you must first [add relevant Tags](/docs/library/tags_metadata) to the Report, and then filter by these Tags when creating a Panel.

title: Overview
description: Introduction to Dashboard.
ai_section:
## What’s Next?
- See how to [customize dashboard via API](/docs/platform/dashboard_add_panels).
- See how to [customize dashboard via UI](/docs/platform/dashboard_add_panels_ui).

title: Dashboard panel types [Legacy]
description: Overview of the available monitoring Panels.
ai_section:
## Monitoring Panel Overview
A monitoring Panel is an individual plot or counter on the Monitoring Dashboard. You can add multiple Panels and organize them by **Tabs**, customizing Panel type, values shown, titles, and legends. When adding a Panel, you choose a **Test** or **Metric** to pull corresponding values from Reports in the Project. You can use **Tags** to filter data from specific Reports.

title: Dashboard panel types [Legacy]
description: Overview of the available monitoring Panels.
ai_section:
## Panel Types
There are three main panel types:

1. **Metric Panels**: Plot individual values from Reports.
2. **Test Panels**: Show pass/fail Test outcomes over time.
3. **Distribution Panels**: Plot distributions over time.

title: Dashboard panel types [Legacy]
description: Overview of the available monitoring Panels.
ai_section:
## Metric Panels
Metric Panels (`DashboardPanel`) display individual values from Reports over time. For example, this can include mean, max, min values from Data Summary Reports or Data Drift Reports. 

**Panel time resolution** varies with Report frequency—daily logged Reports allow daily granularity.

### Counter
Class `DashboardPanelCounter` shows a value with supporting text, making it useful for dashboard titles.

### Plot
Class `DashboardPanelPlot` displays values as bar, line, scatter plot, or histogram.

title: Dashboard panel types [Legacy]
description: Overview of the available monitoring Panels.
ai_section:
## Test Panels
Test Panels visualize Test results, allowing you to see pass/fail outcomes or result counts over repeated Tests. These panels work only with Test Suites.

### Test Counter
Class `DashboardPanelTestSuiteCounter` shows a counter of Tests with specified status.

### Test Plot
Class `DashboardPanelTestSuite` presents individual results or aggregates based on selected Test types.

title: Dashboard panel types [Legacy]
description: Overview of the available monitoring Panels.
ai_section:
## Distribution Panel
Class `DashboardPanelDistribution` displays the distribution of values over time. It can be used to track how the frequency of categories changes in captured evaluations.

**Comparison with Histogram**: A Histogram shows the distribution of selected values, while a Distribution Panel demonstrates how this distribution alters over time.

title: Dashboard panel types [Legacy]
description: Overview of the available monitoring Panels.
ai_section:
## Adding Dashboard Panels
This section describes how to add panels one by one and mentions using [pre-built Tabs](/docs/platform/dashboard_tabs) for a quick start.

### Adding Tabs
Multiple Tabs are available in Evidently Cloud and Enterprise. You can add Tabs to organize Panels. 

**User Interface**: Enter "Edit" mode and click the plus sign to add Tabs.

**Python**: Use `create_tab` to add a Tab programmatically.

title: Dashboard panel types [Legacy]
description: Overview of the available monitoring Panels.
ai_section:
## Adding Panels (User Interface)
To add Panels in the User Interface:

1. Enter "Edit" mode.
2. Click on "Add panel".
3. Configure dashboard name, type, etc.
4. Preview and publish.

To delete/edit a Panel, hover over the Panel in Edit mode.

title: Dashboard panel types [Legacy]
description: Overview of the available monitoring Panels.
ai_section:
## Adding Panels (Python API)
You can also add Panels using the Python API. Here's the general flow:

1. Connect to your Project using `ws.get_project("YOUR PROJECT ID HERE")`.
2. Use the `add_panel` method to configure and add a new Panel.
3. Save with `project.save()`.

**Delete Panels**: To remove all Panels, use `project.dashboard.panels = []`.

title: Dashboard panel types [Legacy]
description: Overview of the available monitoring Panels.
ai_section:
## Panel Parameters
General parameters for all Panel types include:

- `title`: The name visible at the header.
- `filter`: Defines a subset of Reports from which to display data.
- `size`: Sets the Panel size to half-width or full-width.

title: Dashboard panel types [Legacy]
description: Overview of the available monitoring Panels.
ai_section:
## Counter Panel Details
Class `DashboardPanelCounter` can display both a value count or simply text. Example usage allows creating text-only panels or counting panels based on Test results.

title: Dashboard panel types [Legacy]
description: Overview of the available monitoring Panels.
ai_section:
## Filters
Filters define a subset of Reports from which to display the data. Tags or metadata values you list must be added when logging Reports. See [docs](/docs/library/tags_metadata).

title: Dashboard panel types [Legacy]
description: Overview of the available monitoring Panels.
ai_section:
## Widget Sizes
The `size` parameter sets the Panel size to either half-width or full-sized. Default size is `WidgetSize.FULL`.

title: Dashboard panel types [Legacy]
description: Overview of the available monitoring Panels.
ai_section:
## Counter Panel
The `DashboardPanelCounter` shows a value count or functions as a text-only Panel.

title: Dashboard panel types [Legacy]
description: Overview of the available monitoring Panels.
ai_section:
## Counter Panel - Text Only
To create a Panel with only the Dashboard title, you can use the following example:

```python
project.dashboard.add_panel(
        DashboardPanelCounter(
            title="LLM chatbot monitoring",
            filter=ReportFilter(metadata_values={}, tag_values=[]),
            agg=CounterAgg.NONE,
            size=WidgetSize.FULL,
        ),
        tab="Overview"
    )
project.save()
```

title: Dashboard panel types [Legacy]
description: Overview of the available monitoring Panels.
ai_section:
## Counter Panel - Value Sum
To create a Panel that sums up the number of rows over time, use the following example:

```python
project.dashboard.add_panel(
        DashboardPanelCounter(
            title="Model calls",
            filter=ReportFilter(metadata_values={}, tag_values=[]),
            value=PanelValue(
                metric_args={"metric.metric_id": RowCount().metric_id},
                field_path="value",
                legend="count",
            ),
            text="count",
            agg=CounterAgg.SUM,
            size=WidgetSize.HALF,
        ),
    tab="Overview"
)
project.save()
```

ai_section:
## Plot Panel - Single Value
To plot a single row count as a LINE plot, use the following example:

```python
project.dashboard.add_panel(
        DashboardPanelPlot(
            title="Row count",
            filter=ReportFilter(metadata_values={}, tag_values=[]),
            values=[
                PanelValue(
                    metric_args={"metric.metric_id": RowCount().metric_id},
                    field_path="value",
                    legend="count",
                ),

            size=WidgetSize.HALF,

project.save()
```

## Plot Panel - Multiple Values
To plot min, max, and mean values on the same plot, use this example:

```python
project.dashboard.add_panel(
        DashboardPanelPlot(
            title="Length",
            filter=ReportFilter(metadata_values={}, tag_values=[]),
            values=[
                PanelValue(
                    metric_args={"metric.metric_id": MinValue(column="length").metric_id},
                    field_path="value",
                    legend="min",
                ),
                PanelValue(
                    metric_args={"metric.metric_id": MeanValue(column="length").metric_id},
                    field_path="value",
                    legend="mean",
                ),
                PanelValue(
                    metric_args={"metric.metric_id": MaxValue(column="length").metric_id},
                    field_path="value",
                    legend="max",
                ),
            ],
            plot_type=PlotType.LINE,
            size=WidgetSize.HALF,
        ),
        tab="Overview"
    )
project.save()
```

To plot the distribution of the "refusals" column, use this example:

| `test_filters: List[TestFilter]=[]`           | Select specific Test(s). Without a filter, the Panel considers results from all Tests.                                                                    |
| `statuses: List[statuses]`                    | Status filters for selecting Tests, such as `TestStatus.ERROR`, `TestStatus.FAIL`, `TestStatus.SUCCESS` (default), `TestStatus.WARNING`, `TestStatus.SKIPPED`. |

The `DashboardPanelTestSuite` component portrays Test results over time and can be used in various configurations.

  <Card title="Aggregated plot" img="/images/dashboard/panel_tests_aggregated_hover_example.png">

Here are the parameters applicable to test panels:

- |
| `test_filters: List[TestFilter]`                             | Select specific Test(s). Without a filter, the Panel displays results from all Tests.                                         |
| `statuses: List[statuses]`                                   | Status filters for selecting Tests with specific outcomes. Defaults display all Test statuses.                                  |

ai_section:
## Metric ID Usage
To specify the Metric or Test for plotting on a Panel, use `test_filters` or `metric_args` with `metric_id` or `metric_fingerprint`. Be sure to use the Metric name that was originally logged to the Project.

**Field Path**: In Metric Panels, the `field_path` specifies which result to focus on, with options including `value`, `share`/`count`, or `values`.

| Field Path        | Description                                           | Applicable Metrics                                        | Applicable Panels                       |
|

title: Dashboard panel types [Legacy]
description: Overview of the available monitoring Panels.

title: Dashboard panel types [Legacy]
description: Overview of the available monitoring Panels.
ai_section:
|
| `value`           | Refers to a single result from the Metric.            | Most Metrics                                            | Counter, Plot                           |
| `share` / `count` | Refers to an absolute count or percentage value.    | Metrics like `MissingValueCount`                        | Counter, Plot                           |
| `shares` / `counts`| Refers to histogram visualizations in Metrics.     | Metrics with histogram visuals like `UniqueValueCount`. | Distribution                             |
