## Data Drift
The "Data Drift" section covers how to customize data drift detection. Understanding and modifying this aspect is crucial for maintaining the relevance and accuracy of machine learning models over time.

title: Classification
description: Overview of the Classification Quality Preset
ai_section:
## Pre-requisites
Before using the `ClassificationPreset`, ensure you are familiar with the following:
* How to use [Data Definition](/docs/library/data_definition) to prepare your data.
* How to create [Reports](/docs/library/report).

title: Classification
description: Overview of the Classification Quality Preset
ai_section:
## Report Overview
The `ClassificationPreset` enables evaluation and visualization of classification task performance, applicable to binary and multi-class classifications. You can run this report on a single dataset or compare against a reference dataset, such as previous performance or different model prompts.

title: Classification
description: Overview of the Classification Quality Preset
ai_section:
## Running a Report on Current Dataset
To run a Preset on a single current dataset, you can use the following code snippet:

```python
report = Report([
    ClassificationPreset(),
])
my_eval = report.run(current, None)
```

title: Classification
description: Overview of the Classification Quality Preset
ai_section:
## Running Tests with Evaluation
To include pass/fail classification quality tests that are auto-generated from the `ref` dataset, use the following:

```python
report = Report([
    ClassificationPreset(),
],
include_tests=True)
my_eval = report.run(current, ref)
```

title: Classification
description: Overview of the Classification Quality Preset
ai_section:
## Available Metrics and Visualizations
The report provides a variety of metrics and visualizations, including:
* **Metrics**: Accuracy, Precision, Recall, F1-score, ROC AUC, LogLoss, etc.
* **Visualizations**: Class Representation, Confusion Matrix, Class Separation Quality, Probability Distribution, ROC Curve, PR Curve, etc.

If feature columns are included, the report will illustrate Classification Quality by column, highlighting the relationship between features and the target.

title: Classification
description: Overview of the Classification Quality Preset
ai_section:
## Test Suite Functionality
The Test Suite enables automatic checks to assess model performance metrics. These tests are generated:
* **Based on a reference dataset**: Conditions like expected prediction accuracy are derived from it.
* **Based on heuristics**: If there is no reference dataset, Evidently creates a dummy classification model as a baseline.

title: Classification
description: Overview of the Classification Quality Preset
ai_section:
## Use Cases for Classification Presets
Classification Presets are applicable in various scenarios:
* **Model/System Comparison**: Evaluate performance across different datasets, useful for A/B testing and experimenting with prompt configurations.
* **Production Monitoring**: Run evaluations upon receiving true labels in production to visualize performance and inform model updates.
* **Debugging**: Investigate performance drop with visual reports.

title: Classification
description: Overview of the Classification Quality Preset
ai_section:
## Data Requirements
To effectively use the Classification Preset, the following data requirements should be met:
* **Target and Prediction Columns**: Crucial for calculating performance.
* **One or Two Datasets**: Use two datasets for side-by-side comparisons or auto-generated tests.
* (Optional) **Input Features**: Include for exploring column-target relationships.
* (Optional) **Timestamp**: Pass it if available for some plots.

title: Classification
description: Overview of the Classification Quality Preset
ai_section:
## Report Customization Options
You can customize the report in various ways:
* **Change Test Conditions**: Modify auto-generated conditions to your specific requirements.
* **Modify Report Composition**: Add additional metrics such as column Correlations, Missing Values, or Data Drift.

title: Classification
description: Overview of the Classification Quality Preset
ai_section:
## Additional Resources
For further information:
* **Data Schema Mapping**: Refer to the [data definition](/docs/library/data_definition).
* **Creating a Custom Report**: Consult the documentation on how to create a [custom Report](/docs/library/report) and modify [Tests](/docs/library/tests).

title: Data Drift
description: Overview of the Data Drift Preset.
ai_section:
## Pre-requisites
Before running a data drift evaluation, ensure you are familiar with the following:
* How to use [Data Definition](https://your-url/docs/library/data_definition) to prepare your data.
* How to create [Reports](https://your-url/docs/library/report).

title: Data Drift
description: Overview of the Data Drift Preset.
ai_section:
## Report Usage
To run a Preset comparing `current` data to `ref` data, use the following code snippet:

```python
report = Report([
    DataDriftPreset(),
])

my_eval = report.run(current, ref)
```

If you want to add Tests with explicit pass/fail for each column, implement this code:

```python
report = Report([
    DataDriftPreset(),
],
include_tests=True)

my_eval = report.run(current, ref)
```

title: Data Drift
description: Overview of the Data Drift Preset.
ai_section:
## Overview of DataDriftPreset
The `DataDriftPreset` evaluates shifts in data distribution between two datasets to detect significant changes.

Key features include:
* **Column drift:** Checks for shifts in each column using an automatic drift detection method based on column type and observations.
* **Target / Prediction Drift:** Evaluates prediction or target values alongside other columns.
* **Overall dataset drift:** Indicates the share of drifting columns; a dataset is considered to have drift if at least 50% of columns drift.

You can sort rows by feature name or type and view individual columns for detailed distribution insights.

title: Data Drift
description: Overview of the Data Drift Preset.
ai_section:
## Use Cases for Data Drift Evaluation
Data drift can be evaluated in various situations including:
* **Monitoring ML model performance without ground truth:** Use feature and prediction drift as proxy metrics when true labels are unavailable. 
* **Debugging ML model quality decay:** Evaluate data drift to understand changes in feature patterns and identify quality drops.
* **Understanding model drift in offline environments:** Analyze historical data drift to define optimal detection and retraining strategies.
* **Deciding on model retraining:** Check for data drift before introducing new data to avoid unnecessary retraining.

title: Data Drift
description: Overview of the Data Drift Preset.
ai_section:
## Data Requirements for Drift Evaluation
To effectively evaluate drift, adhere to the following data requirements:
* **Input columns:** Must be non-empty.
* **Two datasets:** Always compare current data against a reference dataset.
* **Set column types (optional):** Specify column types (numerical, categorical, text) explicitly for better accuracy. Otherwise, the system will auto-detect these.

title: Data Drift
description: Overview of the Data Drift Preset.
ai_section:
## Customizing Reports
You have multiple options to customize your reports:
* **Select columns:** Focus drift detection on specific columns using the `columns` parameter.
* **Change drift parameters:** Modify detection methods, thresholds, or implement custom methods.
* **Modify report composition:** Add additional metrics to the report for comprehensive evaluation, including evaluating a separate target/prediction column or adding data quality checks.

For further details, visit the [Drift Customization](https://your-url/metrics/customize_data_drift) section.

title: Data Summary
description: Overview of the Data Summary Preset.
ai_section:
## Pre-requisites
To effectively use the features discussed, ensure you are familiar with the following:
* Using [Data Definition](/docs/library/data_definition) to prepare your data.
* Creating [Reports](/docs/library/report).

title: Data Summary
description: Overview of the Data Summary Preset.
ai_section:
## Report Execution
To run a Preset on your data for a single `current` dataset, use the following code snippet:

```python
report = Report([
    DataSummaryPreset(),
])

my_eval = report.run(current, None)
```

title: Data Summary
description: Overview of the Data Summary Preset.
ai_section:
## Test Suite
To incorporate pass/fail data quality Tests generated from a `ref` dataset, implement this code:

```python
report = Report([
    DataSummaryPreset(),
],
include_tests=True)

my_eval = report.run(current, ref)
```

title: Data Summary
description: Overview of the Data Summary Preset.
ai_section:
## Overview of DataSummaryPreset
The `DataSummaryPreset` allows you to visualize key descriptive statistics for the dataset and each column. Providing two datasets will enable a side-by-side comparison.

**Dataset stats.** Show statistics like the number of rows/columns, and counts of empty columns/rows.

**Column stats.** Display relevant statistics and visualize distributions for each column type—including numerical, categorical, text, and datetime.

If Tests are enabled, an additional Test Suite view will be available.

title: Data Summary
description: Overview of the Data Summary Preset.
ai_section:
## How Tests Work
Tests are auto-generated under two scenarios:

* **Based on reference dataset.** If a reference dataset is provided, conditions like minimum and maximum feature ranges will be derived from it.
* **Based on heuristics.** If no reference is provided, some Tests will run using heuristics, such as expecting no missing values.

For more information about Tests, refer to [Tests](/docs/library/tests) and the [reference table](/metrics/all_metrics).

title: Data Summary
description: Overview of the Data Summary Preset.
ai_section:
## Use Cases for DataSummaryPreset
You can apply this Preset in several scenarios:

* **Exploratory data analysis.** Utilize the visual Report for dataset exploration during model training, after new data arrives, or while debugging.
* **Dataset comparison.** Compare any datasets to identify differences—such as training vs. test datasets or current production data against training.
* **Data quality tests in production.** Enable Tests to check quality and stability of input data before generating predictions or processing transformations.
* **Data profiling in production.** Use this Preset to monitor and analyze the shape of production data for future visualization.

title: Data Summary
description: Overview of the Data Summary Preset.
ai_section:
## Data Requirements
To effectively use the DataSummaryPreset, ensure the following data criteria are met:

* **Input columns.** Any input columns can be provided but must be non-empty.
* **One or two datasets.** Pass one dataset for a general summary or two for side-by-side comparisons and test auto-generation.
* **(Optional) Set column types.** While it's recommended to explicitly specify column types, the presetter will auto-detect types like numerical and categorical. Text data must always be mapped.

For guidelines on data schema mapping, refer to [data definition](/docs/library/data_definition).

title: Data Summary
description: Overview of the Data Summary Preset.
ai_section:
## Report Customization
You have various options to customize your Report:

**Select columns.** Use the `columns` parameter for stats only on specific columns.

**Modify Report composition.** Add other Metrics for a comprehensive assessment, such as:
* **Correlations.** Include correlations heatmap.
* **Missing values.** Add a missing values heatmap and monitor data quality.
* **Data drift.** Evaluate distribution shifts between datasets.

**Customize Test conditions.** Alter auto-generated Test conditions by setting your own, whether different from the reference or entirely custom for each Test.

For more details on creating a [Report](/docs/library/report) and adding [Tests](/docs/library/tests), refer to the documentation.

title: Recommendations
description: Overview of the Recommender Systems Preset

title: Recommendations
description: Overview of the Recommender Systems Preset
ai_section:
## Running a Report
To run a Preset on your data for a single current dataset for top-k recommendations, use the following code:

```python
report = Report([
    RecSysPreset(k=5),
])

my_eval = report.run(current, None)
```

title: Recommendations
description: Overview of the Recommender Systems Preset
ai_section:
## Test Suite Overview
To add pass/fail ranking quality Tests, which are auto-generated from the `ref` dataset, use:

```python
report = Report([
    RecSysPreset(k=5),
],
include_tests=True)

my_eval = report.run(current, ref)
```

title: Recommendations
description: Overview of the Recommender Systems Preset
ai_section:
## RecsysPreset Overview
`RecsysPreset` evaluates the quality of the recommender system by generating multiple metrics to assess the quality of ranking and diversity of recommendations. You must provide the `k` parameter to evaluate the Top-K recommendations. It includes 10+ metrics like NDCG at K, MAP at K, HitRate, diversity, serendipity, etc. Metric selection depends on the data provided.

<Info>
  **Metric explainers.** Check the [Ranking and RecSys Metrics](/metrics/explainer_recsys) to see how each Metric works.
</Info>

title: Recommendations
description: Overview of the Recommender Systems Preset
ai_section:
## Automatic Test Suite
If you enable Tests, the system will automatically run checks to assess if the model performance metrics are within bounds. Tests are auto-generated based on the reference dataset. If provided, conditions like expected ranking accuracy will be derived from it.

<Info>
  **How Tests work.** Read about [Tests](/docs/library/tests) and check defaults for each Test in the [reference table](/metrics/all_metrics).
</Info>

title: Recommendations
description: Overview of the Recommender Systems Preset
ai_section:
## Use Cases for Presets
These Presets are useful in various scenarios:

* **Experimental evaluations** as you iterate on building your recommender system.
* **Side-by-side comparison** for two different models or periods.
* **Production monitoring** checks after acquiring ground truth labels.
* **Debugging** to investigate any drop in performance using the visual Report.

title: Recommendations
description: Overview of the Recommender Systems Preset
ai_section:
## Data Requirements
To effectively use the Presets, you need to fulfill the following data requirements:

* **Prediction:** Recommended items with rank or score.
* **Target:** True relevance score or interaction result.
* **(Optional) Input/user features:** For some diversity metrics.
* **(Optional) Training data:** For some diversity metrics.
* **(Optional) Reference dataset:** For side-by-side comparison or auto-generated test conditions.

<Info>
  **Data schema mapping.** Use the [data definition](/docs/library/data_definition) to map your input data.
</Info>

title: Recommendations
description: Overview of the Recommender Systems Preset
ai_section:
## Report Customization Options
You can customize the Report in various ways:

* **Change Test conditions:** Modify the auto-generated conditions, either relative to the reference or any custom conditions.
* **Modify Report composition:** Add metrics like Data Drift for user or item feature distributions, or evaluate prediction drift.

<Info>
  **Custom Report.** Check how to create a [Report](/docs/library/report) and add [Tests](/docs/library/tests) conditions.
</Info>

title: Regression
description: Overview of the Regression Quality Preset
ai_section:
## Pre-requisites
Before you begin, make sure you are familiar with how to use [Data Definition](/docs/library/data_definition) to prepare the data and how to create [Reports](/docs/library/report).

title: Regression
description: Overview of the Regression Quality Preset
ai_section:
## Running a Basic Report
To run a Preset on your data for a single current dataset, use the following code:

```python
report = Report([
    RegressionPreset(),
])

my_eval = report.run(current, None)
```

title: Regression
description: Overview of the Regression Quality Preset
ai_section:
## Adding Tests to Your Report
To add pass/fail regression quality Tests that are auto-generated from the `ref` dataset, use this code:

```python
report = Report([
    RegressionPreset(),
],
include_tests=True)

my_eval = report.run(current, ref)
```

title: Regression
description: Overview of the Regression Quality Preset
ai_section:
## Overview of RegressionPreset
The `RegressionPreset` allows you to evaluate and visualize performance on regression tasks. You can run a Report for a single dataset or compare it against a reference dataset (e.g., past performance or a different model/prompt).

### Report Features
The Report includes various metrics like Mean Absolute Error (MAE), Mean Squared Error (MSE), and visualizations such as Actual vs Predicted Plot and Error Distribution.

If Tests are enabled, they automatically run checks to assess if the model performance metrics are within bounds.

title: Regression
description: Overview of the Regression Quality Preset
ai_section:
## How Tests Work
Tests are auto-generated based on the reference dataset provided or, in the absence of a reference, a dummy regression model is created to run checks against it. For more details on how Tests function and the defaults for each Test, refer to [Tests](/docs/library/tests) and the [reference table](/metrics/all_metrics).

title: Regression
description: Overview of the Regression Quality Preset
ai_section:
## Use Cases for Regression Presets
These Presets are particularly useful in various scenarios:

- **Model/System Comparison**: Compare predictive system performance across different datasets, useful for A/B testing and experimenting with model configurations.
  
- **Production Monitoring**: Run evaluations whenever actual values are received in production to visualize performance and decide on model updates or retraining.

- **Debugging**: When performance drops, use the visual Report to check error distributions and explore model errors.

title: Regression
description: Overview of the Regression Quality Preset
ai_section:
## Data Requirements for Reporting
To successfully generate a Report, the following data requirements must be met:

- **Target and Prediction Columns**: These are required to calculate performance metrics.
  
- **One or Two Datasets**: Pass two datasets for side-by-side comparisons or to auto-generate tests.

- **Optional Inputs**: You can include input features for exploring underperforming segments and a timestamp to appear on some plots.

For data schema mapping, refer to the [data definition](/docs/library/data_definition).

title: Regression
description: Overview of the Regression Quality Preset
ai_section:
## Customizing Your Report
You can customize the Report in several ways:

- **Change Test Conditions**: Modify the auto-generated conditions or set your own conditions relative to the reference or custom thresholds.

- **Modify Report Composition**: Add additional metrics such as column Correlations, Missing Values, or Data Drift, which can be useful for evaluating statistical distribution shifts in the model target (concept drift).

For guidance on creating a [Report](/docs/library/report) and adding [Tests](/docs/library/tests), consult the relevant documentation.

title: Text Evals
description: Overview of the Text Evals Preset.
ai_section:
## Running the Report
To run a Preset on your data for a single `current` dataset, start by computing `descriptors` and adding them to your Dataset. Here’s how you can do it:

```python
report = Report(metrics=[
    TextEvals(),
])

my_eval = report.run(current, None)
```

title: Text Evals
description: Overview of the Text Evals Preset.
ai_section:
## Test Suite
To add pass/fail data quality Tests that are auto-generated from a `ref` dataset, you can enable this feature in your Report:

```python
report = Report([
    TextEvals(),
],
include_tests=True)

my_eval = report.run(current, ref)
```

title: Text Evals
description: Overview of the Text Evals Preset.
ai_section:
## Overview of TextEvals
The `TextEvals` Preset summarizes results of all **descriptors** (output-level text evaluations) computed on your dataset. It provides a visual exploration of distributions and captures relevant statistics, which may vary based on descriptor type. If two datasets are provided, a side-by-side comparison will be generated.

<Info>
  **How text and LLM evaluations work.** Read about [Descriptors](/docs/library/descriptors), or try a [Quickstart](/quickstart_llm).
</Info>

title: Text Evals
description: Overview of the Text Evals Preset.
ai_section:
## Test Suite Functionality
If the Test Suite is enabled, an additional view presents:

* **Reference Dataset**: If provided, expected descriptor values are derived from it.
* **Heuristic-Based Tests**: If no reference is available, some Tests will run based on heuristics, such as expecting no missing values.

<Info>
  **How Tests work.** Read about [Tests](/docs/library/tests) and check defaults for each Test in the [reference table.](/metrics/all_metrics)
</Info>

title: Text Evals
description: Overview of the Text Evals Preset.
ai_section:
## Use Cases for TextEvals
The Preset can be used in various scenarios, including:

* **LLM experiments**: Create visual Reports to explore evaluation results during prompt or model version experiments, enabling comparisons between different runs.
* **LLM observability**: Evaluate production data to capture statistics over time.

title: Text Evals
description: Overview of the Text Evals Preset.
ai_section:
## Data Requirements
To utilize this Report, you’ll need:

* **Input dataset with descriptors**: Ensure your Dataset includes computed descriptors (see [how](/docs/library/descriptors)).
* **One or two datasets**: You can pass either a single dataset or two for comparison or to auto-generate test conditions.

<Info>
  **Data schema mapping**. Use the [data definition](/docs/library/data_definition) to map your input data.
</Info>

title: Text Evals
description: Overview of the Text Evals Preset.
ai_section:
## Report Customization Options
You can customize your Report in several ways:

**Select descriptors**: Specify seen descriptors in the Dataset using the `columns` parameter.

**Customize Test conditions**: Set your own conditions, like failing if texts exceed or fall below a specified Length Range. Refer to a [Quickstart example](/quickstart_llm).

**Modify Report composition**: Incorporate additional Metrics for a more comprehensive evaluation. Options include:

* **Correlations**: Use a correlations heatmap to analyze connections between descriptor values or with metadata in the Dataset.
* **Data drift**: Measure data drift for comparing descriptor distributions between two datasets.

<Info>
  **Custom Report**. Check how to create a [Report](/docs/library/report) and add [Tests](/docs/library/tests) conditions.
</Info>

title: LLM Evaluation
description: Evaluate text outputs in under 5 minutes
ai_section:
## Overview of Evidently
Evidently helps you evaluate LLM outputs automatically. It allows you to compare prompts, models, and run regression or adversarial tests with clear, repeatable checks, leading to faster iterations, more confident decisions, and fewer surprises in production.

title: LLM Evaluation
description: Evaluate text outputs in under 5 minutes
ai_section:
## Getting Help
Need help at any point? Ask on [Discord](https://discord.com/invite/xZjKRaNp8b).

title: LLM Evaluation
description: Evaluate text outputs in under 5 minutes
ai_section:
## 1. Set up your environment
For a fully local flow, skip steps 1.1 and 1.3.

### 1.1. Set up Evidently Cloud
<CloudSignup />

### 1.2. Installation and imports
Install the Evidently Python library:

```python
!pip install evidently
```

Components to run the evals:

```python
import pandas as pd
from evidently import Dataset
from evidently import DataDefinition
from evidently import Report
from evidently.presets import TextEvals
from evidently.tests import lte, gte, eq
from evidently.descriptors import LLMEval, TestSummary, DeclineLLMEval, Sentiment, TextLength, IncludesWords
from evidently.llm.templates import BinaryClassificationPromptTemplate
```

Components to connect with Evidently Cloud:

```python
from evidently.ui.workspace import CloudWorkspace
```

### 1.3. Create a Project
<CreateProject />

title: LLM Evaluation
description: Evaluate text outputs in under 5 minutes
ai_section:
## 2. Prepare the dataset
Let's create a toy demo chatbot dataset with "Questions" and "Answers".

```python
data = [
    ["What is the chemical symbol for gold?", "Gold chemical symbol is Au."],
    ["What is the capital of Japan?", "The capital of Japan is Tokyo."],
    ["Tell me a joke.", "Why don't programmers like nature? Too many bugs!"],
    ["When does water boil?", "Water's boiling point is 100 degrees Celsius."],
    ["Who painted the Mona Lisa?", "Leonardo da Vinci painted the Mona Lisa."],
    ["What’s the fastest animal on land?", "The cheetah is the fastest land animal, capable of running up to 75 miles per hour."],
    ["Can you help me with my math homework?", "I'm sorry, but I can't assist with homework."],
    ["How many states are there in the USA?", "USA has 50 states."],
    ["What’s the primary function of the heart?", "The primary function of the heart is to pump blood throughout the body."],
    ["Can you tell me the latest stock market trends?", "I'm sorry, but I can't provide real-time stock market trends. You might want to check a financial news website or consult a financial advisor."]
]
columns = ["question", "answer"]

eval_df = pd.DataFrame(data, columns=columns)
```

title: LLM Evaluation
description: Evaluate text outputs in under 5 minutes
ai_section:
## Customizing Your Dataset
**Preparing your own data**: You can provide data with any structure, such as:
- Inputs and outputs from your LLM
- Inputs, outputs, and reference outputs (for comparison)
- Inputs, context, and outputs (for RAG evaluation)

**Collecting live data**: You can also trace inputs and outputs from your LLM app and download the dataset from traces. See the [Tracing Quickstart](/quickstart_tracing).

title: LLM Evaluation
description: Evaluate text outputs in under 5 minutes
ai_section:
## 3. Run evaluations
We'll evaluate the answers for:

- **Sentiment:** from -1 (negative) to 1 (positive)
- **Text length:** character count
- **Denials:** refusals to answer. This uses an LLM-as-a-judge with a built-in prompt.

Set the OpenAI key as an environment variable:

```python
## import os
## os.environ["OPENAI_API_KEY"] = "YOUR KEY"
```

If you don't have an OpenAI key, you can use a keyword-based check `IncludesWords` instead.

To run evals, pass the dataset and specify the list of descriptors to add:

```python
eval_dataset = Dataset.from_pandas(
    eval_df,
    data_definition=DataDefinition(),
    descriptors=[
        Sentiment("answer", alias="Sentiment"),
        TextLength("answer", alias="Length"),
        DeclineLLMEval("answer", alias="Denials")
    ]
)
```

**Congratulations!** You've just run your first eval. Preview the results locally in pandas:

```python
eval_dataset.as_dataframe()
```

title: LLM Evaluation
description: Evaluate text outputs in under 5 minutes
ai_section:
## Available Evaluations
**What other evals are there?** Browse all available descriptors including deterministic checks, semantic similarity, and LLM judges in the [descriptor list](/metrics/all_descriptors).

title: LLM Evaluation
description: Evaluate text outputs in under 5 minutes
ai_section:
## 4. Create a Report
**Create and run a Report**. It will summarize the evaluation results.

```python
report = Report([TextEvals()])
my_eval = report.run(eval_dataset, None)
```

**Local preview**: In a Python environment like Jupyter notebook or Colab, run:

```python
my_eval
```

You can also export results as JSON, Python dictionary, or save as an external HTML file.

```python
# my_eval.json()
# my_eval.dict()
# my_report.save_html(“file.html”)
```

**Upload the Report to Evidently Cloud** together with scored data:

```python
ws.add_run(project.id, my_eval, include_data=True)
```

**Explore**: Go to [Evidently Cloud](https://app.evidently.cloud/), open your Project, and navigate to Reports for score summaries and data browsing.

title: LLM Evaluation
description: Evaluate text outputs in under 5 minutes
ai_section:
## 5. Get a Dashboard
As you run more evals, track them over time. Go to "Dashboard" in the left menu, enter "Edit" mode, and add a new "Columns" tab.

You'll see a set of panels with descriptor values. Each will have a single data point initially. As you log more evaluations, track trends and set up alerts.

title: LLM Evaluation
description: Evaluate text outputs in under 5 minutes
ai_section:
## 6. (Optional) Add tests
You can add conditions to your evaluations. For example, you may expect that:

- **Sentiment** is non-negative (greater or equal to 0)
- **Text length** is at most 150 symbols (less or equal to 150)
- **Denials**: there are none

You can implement this logic easily.

```python
# Run the evaluation with tests 
eval_dataset = Dataset.from_pandas(
    eval_df,
    data_definition=DataDefinition(),
    descriptors=[
        Sentiment("answer", alias="Sentiment", tests=[gte(0, alias="Is_non_negative")]),
        TextLength("answer", alias="Length", tests=[lte(150, alias="Has_expected_length")]),
        DeclineLLMEval("answer", alias="Denials", tests=[eq("OK", column="Denials", alias="Is_not_a_refusal")]),
        TestSummary(success_all=True, alias="All_tests_passed")
    ]
)
```

title: LLM Evaluation
description: Evaluate text outputs in under 5 minutes
ai_section:
## 7. (Optional) Add a custom LLM judge
You can implement custom criteria using built-in LLM judge templates.

For instance, classify user questions as "appropriate" or "inappropriate":

```python
# Define the evaluation criteria
appropriate_scope = BinaryClassificationPromptTemplate(
    criteria="""An appropriate question is any educational query related to
    academic subjects, general school-level world knowledge, or skills.
    An inappropriate question is anything offensive, irrelevant, or out of
    scope.""",
    target_category="APPROPRIATE",
    non_target_category="INAPPROPRIATE",
    include_reasoning=True,
)

# Apply evaluation
llm_evals = Dataset.from_pandas(
    eval_df,
    data_definition=DataDefinition(),
    descriptors=[
        LLMEval("question", template=appropriate_scope,
                provider="openai", model="gpt-4o-mini",
                alias="Question topic")
    ]
)
```

title: LLM Evaluation
description: Evaluate text outputs in under 5 minutes
ai_section:
## What's next?
Read more on how you can configure [LLM judges for custom criteria or using other LLMs](/metrics/customize_llm_judge). We also have lots of other examples; [explore tutorials](/metrics/introduction).

title: Tracing
description: How to capture LLM inputs and outputs and evaluate them.
ai_section:
## 1. Introduction
This tutorial shows how to set up tracing for an LLM app, collect its inputs and outputs, view them in Evidently Cloud, and optionally run evaluations. The tools used include Tracely, Evidently, Evidently Cloud, and OpenAI.

title: Tracing
description: How to capture LLM inputs and outputs and evaluate them.
ai_section:
## 2. Installation
To begin, install the necessary libraries using the following commands:

```python
! pip install evidently
! pip install tracely 
! pip install openai
```

Then, import the required modules:

```python
import os
import openai
import time
import uuid
from tracely import init_tracing
from tracely import trace_event
from tracely import create_trace_event
from evidently.ui.workspace import CloudWorkspace
```

If you want to load the traced dataset back to Python and run evaluations, use the following:

```python
import pandas as pd
from evidently import Dataset
from evidently import DataDefinition
from evidently import Report
from evidently.descriptors import *
from evidently.presets import TextEvals
from evidently.metrics import *
from evidently.tests import *
```

title: Tracing
description: How to capture LLM inputs and outputs and evaluate them.
ai_section:
## 3. Set up workspace
### 3.1. Set up Evidently Cloud
Follow the <CloudSignup /> snippet to set up your Evidently Cloud workspace.

### 3.2. Create a Project
Use the <CreateProject /> snippet to create a new project in Evidently Cloud.

### 3.3. Get Open AI key
Set up the OpenAI key by creating an environment variable. Visit the [Token page](https://platform.openai.com/api-keys) for your key and follow best practices for security as outlined in the [Open AI docs](https://help.openai.com/en/articles/5112595-best-practices-for-api-key-safety).

```python
os.environ["OPENAI_API_KEY"] = "YOUR_KEY"
```

title: Tracing
description: How to capture LLM inputs and outputs and evaluate them.
ai_section:
## 4. Configure tracing
To set up and initialize tracing, use the following code:

```python
project_id = str(project.id)

init_tracing(
 address="https://app.evidently.cloud/",
 api_key="YOUR_API_TOKEN",
 project_id=project_id,
 export_name="TRACING_DATASET"
 )
```

### Important Parameters
- **Address**: The destination backend for storing collected traces.
- **Project ID**: The ID of the Evidently Project created previously. Get it from the [Home page](https://app.evidently.cloud/).
- **Dataset Name**: Used to identify the Tracing dataset.

title: Tracing
description: How to capture LLM inputs and outputs and evaluate them.
ai_section:
## 5. Trace a simple LLM app
Now, create and trace a simple function that sends a list of questions to the LLM. First, initialize the OpenAI client with the API key:

```python
client = openai.OpenAI(api_key=openai_api_key)
```

Define the list of questions:

```python
question_list = [
    "What is Evidently Python library?",
    "What is LLM observability?",
    "How is MLOps different from LLMOps?",
    "What is an LLM prompt?",
    "Why should you care about LLM safety?"
]
```

Use the following function to interact with the LLM and trace the execution:

```python
def qa_assistant(question):
    system_prompt = "You are a helpful assistant. Please answer the following question in one sentence."
    messages = [
        {"role": "system", "content": system_prompt},
        {"role": "user", "content": question},
    ]
    return client.chat.completions.create(model="gpt-4o-mini", messages=messages).choices[0].message.content

# Iterate over the list of questions
for question in question_list:
    session_id = str(uuid.uuid4())
    with create_trace_event("qa", session_id=session_id) as event:
      response = qa_assistant(question=question)
      event.set_attribute("question", question)
      event.set_attribute("response", response)
      time.sleep(1)
```

title: Tracing
description: How to capture LLM inputs and outputs and evaluate them.
ai_section:

```

Then set up descriptors for evaluation:

    SentenceCount("qa.response", alias="SentenceCount"),
    TextLength("qa.response", alias="Length"),

```

Summarize the results in a report and upload it to Evidently Cloud:

```python

    TextEvals()
])

ws.add_run(project.id, my_eval, include_data=True)
```

After running the evaluation, open the Report in your Project:

![](/images/examples/tracing_tutorial_evals.png)

For additional details on running evaluations, check the quickstart on [LLM evaluations](/quickstart_llm) and explore other evaluation methods. If you need help, feel free to ask in our [Discord community](https://discord.com/invite/xZjKRaNp8b).

## Sign Up for Evidently Cloud
To start using Evidently Cloud, you need to sign up for a free account. You can do this by visiting the following link: [Evidently Cloud Sign-Up](https://app.evidently.cloud/signup).

## Create an Organization
Upon your first login, you will need to create an organization. This step involves obtaining an ID for your organization. For more details on how to create an organization, you can visit this link: [Create Organization](https://app.evidently.cloud/organizations).

## Get an API Token
To interact with the Evidently Cloud API, you must generate an API token. Click the **Key** icon in the left menu to generate and save your token. More information on this process can be found here: [Get API Token](https://app.evidently.cloud/token).

## Connecting to Evidently Cloud
To connect to Evidently Cloud, use your API token in the following way:

```python
ws = CloudWorkspace(token="YOUR_API_TOKEN", url="https://app.evidently.cloud")
```

## Creating a Project
To create a new Project within your Organization or to connect to an existing Project, use the following code:

```python
project = ws.create_project("My project name", org_id="YOUR_ORG_ID")
project.description = "My project description"
project.save()

# or project = ws.get_project("PROJECT_ID")
```
This allows you to manage projects effectively by either creating new ones or accessing existing ones.

title: Adversarial testing
description: Synthetic edge cases and tricky inputs
ai_section:
## Overview of Adversarial Tests
Adversarial tests are designed to challenge AI models by exposing weaknesses and vulnerabilities. These inputs may attempt to bypass safety protections, trick the model into revealing sensitive information, or exploit edge cases to evaluate system robustness. Evidently Cloud allows automation of adversarial test generation based on defined risk categories.

title: Adversarial testing
description: Synthetic edge cases and tricky inputs
ai_section:
## Create an Adversarial Test Dataset
You can configure your own adversarial dataset by following a simple process within the Evidently UI.

title: Adversarial testing
description: Synthetic edge cases and tricky inputs
ai_section:
## Step 1: Create a Project
To start, either create a new project or open an existing one in the Evidently UI. Navigate to “Datasets” in the left menu, click “Generate,” and select the “Adversarial testing” option.

title: Adversarial testing
description: Synthetic edge cases and tricky inputs
ai_section:
## Step 2: Select a Test Scenario
Choose a predefined adversarial scenario from the following categories:
- Harmful content (e.g., profanity, toxicity, illegal advice)
- Forbidden topics (e.g., financial, legal, medical queries)
- Brand image (eliciting negative feedback on a company or product)
- Competition (comparisons with competitor products)
- Offers and promises (attempting to get AI to make commitments)
- Hijacking (out-of-scope questions unrelated to intended purpose)
- Prompt leakage (extracting system instructions or hidden prompts)

title: Adversarial testing
description: Synthetic edge cases and tricky inputs
ai_section:
## Step 3: Configure the Dataset
After selecting a scenario, you can provide an optional dataset name and description, set the number of inputs to generate, and customize specific categories like forbidden topics.

title: Adversarial testing
description: Synthetic edge cases and tricky inputs
ai_section:
## Step 4: Generate the Data
You have the option to:
- Combine multiple scenarios into a single dataset, with a separate "scenario" column for each test case.
- Export each scenario separately to generate individual datasets for each selected type.

Once generated, you can open, edit, or download each dataset as a CSV file or access it via the Python API using the dataset ID.

title: Adversarial testing
description: Synthetic edge cases and tricky inputs
ai_section:
## Dataset API
For more information on working with Evidently datasets, you can refer to the [Evidently datasets documentation](https://docs/platform/datasets_overview).

title: Create synthetic inputs
description: Generate input test cases.
ai_section:
## Overview of Synthetic Input Generation
Synthetic input generation allows you to create test questions from descriptions and examples. This helps expand test coverage and evaluate how your AI system handles different types of queries. You can use this to generate test questions for RAG systems without predefined answers, create adversarial inputs by describing specific edge cases, and generate questions tailored to specific user personas for more targeted testing.

title: Create synthetic inputs
description: Generate input test cases.
ai_section:
## Create Synthetic Inputs
You can generate example inputs specific to your LLM app context through a structured process.

title: Create synthetic inputs
description: Generate input test cases.
ai_section:
## Step 1: Create a Project
In the Evidently UI, you can start a new Project or open an existing one. To do this:
- Navigate to “Datasets” in the left menu.
- Click “Generate” and select the “Generate from examples” option.

![Project Creation](/images/synthetic/synthetic_data_select_method.png)

title: Create synthetic inputs
description: Generate input test cases.
ai_section:
## Step 2: Describe the Scenario
Define the inputs you need by providing a brief description of the task and choosing how many inputs to generate. For example, if you’re building a travel assistant, you might enter:
- Description: "Questions a person can ask when planning a trip"
- Example input: "What can I do in Paris in a day?"

This helps guide the system in generating relevant and diverse inputs. You can also provide a more detailed prompt.

![Scenario Description](/images/synthetic/synthetic_data_inputs_example_prompt.png)

title: Create synthetic inputs
description: Generate input test cases.
ai_section:
## Step 3: Review the Results
Once you describe the scenario, the system will generate a list of input questions based on your description. You can preview and refine the generated dataset, allowing you to:
- Use “More like this” to generate additional variations.
- Drop questions that don’t fit your needs.
- Manually edit or rephrase questions.

![Review Results](/images/synthetic/synthetic_data_inputs_example_result.png)

After finalizing your selections, you can save the dataset. Options include downloading it as a CSV file or accessing it via the Python API using the dataset ID.

## Generating Synthetic Test Inputs
Evidently Cloud lets you generate synthetic test inputs (and outputs) to evaluate your AI system. You can use it for:

* **Experiments**: Create test data to see how your LLM app handles it.
* **Regression testing**: Validate changes before deployment.
* **Adversarial testing**: Check how your system handles tricky or unexpected inputs.

Once you generate the data, you can run it through your AI system and evaluate the results using the Evidently Cloud or Evidently Python library as usual.

## Overview of Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) Systems
Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) systems rely on retrieving answers from a knowledge base before generating responses. To evaluate them effectively, you need a test dataset that reflects what the system *should* know.

title: RAG evaluation dataset
description: Synthetic data for RAG.
ai_section:
## Importance of Test Datasets
Instead of manually creating test cases, you can generate them directly from your knowledge source, ensuring accurate and relevant ground truth data.

title: RAG evaluation dataset
description: Synthetic data for RAG.
ai_section:
## Create a RAG Test Dataset
You can generate a ground truth RAG dataset from your data source using the Evidently UI.

title: RAG evaluation dataset
description: Synthetic data for RAG.
ai_section:
## Step 1: Create a Project
In the Evidently UI, start a new Project or open an existing one.
- Navigate to “Datasets” in the left menu.
- Click “Generate” and select the “RAG” option.

title: RAG evaluation dataset
description: Synthetic data for RAG.
ai_section:
## Step 2: Upload Your Knowledge Base
Select a file containing the information your AI system retrieves from. Supported formats include Markdown (.md), CSV, TXT, and PDFs. Choose how many inputs to generate.
- Simply drop the file.
- Choose the number of inputs to generate.
- Decide if you want to include the context used to generate the answer.

<Info>
  Note that it may take some time to process the dataset. Limits apply on the free plan.
</Info>

title: Why synthetic data?
description: When do you need synthetic data in LLM evaluations.
ai_section:
## Importance of Test Data in AI Systems
When working on an AI system, you need test data to run automated evaluations for quality and safety. A test dataset is a structured set of test cases. It can contain just the inputs or both inputs and expected outputs (ground truth). A test dataset serves multiple purposes including running experiments, regression testing, and stress-testing.

title: Why synthetic data?
description: When do you need synthetic data in LLM evaluations.
ai_section:
## Functions of a Test Dataset
You can use a test dataset to:

* Run **experiments** and track if changes improve or degrade system performance.
* Conduct **regression testing** to ensure updates don’t break what was already working.
* **Stress-test** your system with complex or adversarial inputs to check its resilience.

title: Why synthetic data?
description: When do you need synthetic data in LLM evaluations.
ai_section:
## Creating Test Datasets
You can create test datasets manually, collect them from real or historical data, or generate them synthetically. While real data is preferable, it is not always available or sufficient to cover all cases. Public LLM benchmarks help with general model comparisons but don’t reflect your specific use case, and manually writing test cases takes time and effort.

title: Why synthetic data?
description: When do you need synthetic data in LLM evaluations.
ai_section:
## Benefits of Synthetic Data
Synthetic data is especially beneficial when:

* You're starting from scratch and don’t have real data.
* You need to scale a manually designed dataset with more variation.
* You want to test edge cases, adversarial inputs, or system robustness.
* You're evaluating complex AI systems like RAG and AI agents.

title: Why synthetic data?
description: When do you need synthetic data in LLM evaluations.
ai_section:
## Advantages of Using Synthetic Data
Synthetic data is not a replacement for real data or expert-designed tests; it adds variety and speeds up the process. With synthetic data, you can:

* Quickly generate hundreds of structured test cases.
* Fill gaps by adding missing scenarios and tricky inputs.
* Create controlled variations to evaluate specific weaknesses.

title: Why synthetic data?
description: When do you need synthetic data in LLM evaluations.
ai_section:
## Applicability of Synthetic Data for Complex AI Systems
Synthetic data can significantly aid in the evaluation of complex AI systems where designing test cases is challenging. For instance, in RAG evaluation, synthetic data helps create input-output datasets from knowledge bases. In AI agent testing, it enables multi-turn interactions across different scenarios.
